NAME: Italian arrivals
DESC: c 450 Italian refugees from Guat settle on Crown lands at Manatee, engage in farming
NOTE: See D. Koenig, *National Studies* 1(3), May 1973, "What happened to the Italians in British Honduras", 21–23 / L. Bradley, *National Studies* 1(4), Jul 1973, "A Conjecture on the Italians," 29–30 / D. Holdridge, *Geographical Review* 30(3), Jul 1940, "Toledo : A tropical refugee settlement in British Honduras", 376–393 /v Ashdown 136 no 57 /// Possibly see [1878 Sto Tomás] Hubo otro grupo grande de inmigrantes italianos y austríacos que reclutó una compañía en el Tirol, que llegó sin previo aviso a Santo Tomás en 1878, el cual se estableció en asentamientos separados cerca de la capital /v Lujan 4 336

NAME: Barlee affair
DESC: Inhabitants of Colony submit Memorial to Sec of State, praying estimates for 1881 not be approved, information therein being incorrect with view to mislead Colonial Office regarding unsatisfactory financial position of Colony
PRESS: Belize Advertiser 1 1 2 = 21 May 1881 / Belize Advertiser 1 2 1 = 28 May 1881
CF: C.2978 / Pub Affairs xxx [25 Aug 1880, 7 Feb 1881] / R 115 [Memorial ... Sep 1880] / Bel G 1881 xxx [18 Feb 1881]
NOTE: Sep [Aug?] 1880. Memorial fm Inhabitants to Sec of State. States that in 1869 they were induced to consent to abrogation of their popular representative government in favour of Crown Colony system. Afer 10 years regrest grave error committed; opine present system of governemnt is dangerous to best interest of Colony:— Economy and efficiency had been urged as reasons for change, but 10 years experience has shewn reverse is case. Import duty raised; Land, house, property taxes diverted from original purposes; $201,709 squandered since [1 Jan?] 1877; Saving Bank funds illegally used to pay War Dept; ... Leg Co proceedings are little better than mockery, bills being introduced and passed on the same day ... Pray for removal of Lt Gov and his Priv Sec from Leg Co, and retrenchment of Public Expenditure. /R 115 /// 7 Feb 1881 Sec of State to Lt Gov. Instructs additional taxation be imposed, retrenchment of public expenditure, authorises issuance of debentures. /Pub Affairs xxx / 18 Feb 1881. Sec of State, seeing that alterations made in 1869 were carefully considered, cannot hold out any hope that alterations in present Constitution of Legislature will be made, as circumstances of Colony remain unchanged /Bel G 1881 /// See 14 Jun 1881 letter in Times-Picayune 45 123 6 = 23 Jun 1881 Link: https://infoweb-newsbank-com.ezp-prod1.hul.harvard.edu/apps/readex/doc?p=EANX&docref=image/v2%3A1223BCE5B718A166%40EANX-12268AA23A841A40%402408255-1225E5BEB561B9C8%405-126BA6F9E3EB969B%40From%2BThe%2BHonduras / Gov Barlee interview in Times-Picayune Afternoon sn 1 = 7 Aug 1882 Link: https://infoweb-newsbank-com.ezp-prod1.hul.harvard.edu/apps/readex/doc?p=EANX&docref=image/v2%3A1223BCE5B718A166%40EANX-122880CC5DD47598%402408665-12261DF461C01B30%400-12467A14F7EC9750%40Governor%2BBarlee%252C%2BOf%2BBritish%2BHonduras%252C%2BA%2BVisitor%2BTo%2BOur%2BCity.%2BA%2BFew%2BWords%2Bwith%2BHim

NAME: Maya arrivals
DESC: Herman Joseph Cramer, manager of the Cramer Estate in Toledo, imports Maya Q'eqchi' labourers fm Guat
NOTE: See Toledo map in Downey 755 /// 1871 Alta Verapaz. Guat mandamiento law allows Guat Govt to confiscate untitled Maya land /v Downey 753 /// 1891 Census reports 254 residents at San Pedro Landing / 1911 Census reports 328 residents at Dolores /v Downey 758 /xxx /// C 1904 Dolores [Toledo] settled /v Downey 758 /xxx /// 1908–1913 Crique Sarco [Temash R] settled, possibly or likely as camp for logging mill est by Karl Steinbrügge, Herman Steinbrügge /v Downey 760–762 /// 1886 c 100 Mopan Maya fm San Luis [Guat] settle Pueblo Viejo [SE of San Antonio in Toledo] /v Torres R 48, 173 /xxx /// See Richard Wilk, *Belizean Studies* 15(3), "The Kekchi and the Settlement of Toledo District" [1987] /v Ruiz 7 fn 12

NAME: Pound est
DESC: Pound established for stray animals
NOTE: BELIZE, June 15, 1881. Some time in March [1881] we had the pleasure of seeing HE [Gov] ... The next we hear of HE is of his trying to walk the streets amongst the goats, hogs, cattle, horses, mules, etc.; soon a pound was ordered to be built, a proclamation was issued. After a few days notice was given to the police to impound every animal they found in the streets at large; a fine was also imposed on every person having such animal at large of one dollar besides the impounding one dollar also; in a very short time the streets were clear of every animal. /Times-Picayune 45 123

NAME: Vault burials

NOTE: 9 May 1877 New Cemetery opened; Yarborough closed /v Burdon 3 338 /Bel G 1877 /// 24 Dec 1881 Yarborough closed; Vaults at Queen Charlotte's Town opened fm and after 1 Jan 1882 /v Burdon 2 348 /Bel G 1881 /// See account of in Times-Picayune 46 239 Link: https://infoweb-newsbank-com.ezp-prod1.hul.harvard.edu/apps/readex/doc?p=EANX&docref=image/v2%3A1223BCE5B718A166%40EANX-12268A36933D9538%402408710-12261FFAEEC10E20%403-1243C738CF7B1A0A%40An%2BImported%2BNew%2BOrleans%2BGraveyard

NAME: Ycaiche relations crisis
DESC: Trade and intercourse with Icaiche Indians forbidden by Proclamation of Lt Gov Barlee, on account of threat to make war on Colony, but thereafter resumed
PRESS: Belize Advertiser 1 32 3 = 24 Dec 1881 / Belize Advertiser 2 7 2 = 1 Jul 1882 / Colonial Guardian [Belize] 1 23 2 = 10 Jun 1882 / Colonial Guardian [Belize] 1 24 2 = 17 Jun 1882
NOTE: 16 May 1882 Gen Pech to Lt Gov. Warns that Hon residents must evacuate disputed territory near Hondo within a month, or he would "take possession [of the territory] and hoist the Mexican standard" / 29 May 1882 Lt Gov to Gen Pech. Invites him to a round of talks to settle dispute; warns will stop all trade and communication with Icaiche if force is resorted to /v Dutt 139 /CO 123/168 /// 5 Jun 1882 Lt Gov to Kimberley. Reports intel suggesting Pech actions instigated not by foreign elements but rather by "persons in this colony hostile to British rule" /v Dutt 139 /CO 123/167 / 2 Jun 1882 Peña to OWT Mag. Celestino Peña [Sec to Gen Pech] claims Pech ultimatum concocted without Peña's knowledge during Gen Pech visit to San Antonio [Albion Isl] in early May 1882; singles out Albion Isl residents Manuel Jesus Castillo, Jose Santos Lopez, Jose Maria Sevilla, for instigating Pech /v Dutt 139 /CO 123/167 /// 8 Jun 1882 Exec Cl. Informed Gen Pech refused Lt Gov invitation to talks; orders arrest of Castillo and his three associates; orders immediate prohibition of trade and communication with Icaiche /v Dutt 141 /CO 123/167 /// 3 Jul 1882 AG reports sev persons charged with conspiracy to aid invasion of colony by divers foreigners, inc Gen Santiago Pech of Icaiche /v Burdon 3 349 /R 116 /// 12 Jun 1882 Proclamation. Prohibits entrance of any Icaiche Indian for any purpose on pain of imprisonment /Bel G 1882 / 31 Aug 1882 AG to Lt Gov. Reports no "statutory or other authority for the imprisonment of any person found in the Colony under the circumstances stated in Lt Gov letter to Gen Pech [ie 12 Jun 1882 Proclamation]” /v Dutt 144 /CO 123/167 [2 Sep 1882] /// 5 Oct 1882 Lt Gov proposed to recieve Gen Pech at Corozal T /R 120A / 14 Oct 1882 Proclamaiton canceling that of 9 Jun /Bel G 1882 / Oct 1882 Gen Pech signs MOU agreeing to respect Hon boundaries /v Dutt 145 /xxx /// 3 Jul 1882 Mjr Fowler, Lt Garnett lead march to Benque Viejo to restore confidence due to alarm caused by threats by Ycaiche Indians. /Times-Picayune Afternoon sn 2 = 26 Jul 1882 Link: https://infoweb-newsbank-com.ezp-prod1.hul.harvard.edu/apps/readex/doc?p=EANX&docref=image/v2%3A1223BCE5B718A166%40EANX-1228808A1C70B748%402408653-12261DF0B0774D88%401

NAME: R v Castillo
DESC: Manuel Jesus Castillo, Sp refugee resident in Albion Island, and associates, is convicted to 7 yrs imprisonment for treason felony
NON—SP 0: Manuel Jesus Castillo, Jose Santos Lopez, Jose Maria Sevilla
NON—SP 1: AG William Henry Dillet, Messrs Bristowe & Parker [Defence]
NOTE: See pamphlet *A full and particular account of the trial of Manuel Jesus Castillo, Jose Santos Lopez and Jose Maria Sevilla for Treason-Felony* [Belize, sn, sd] /v Dutt 141–142 /xxx /// Possibly see prev cases of Sp refugees charged with treason felony eg 1867 Marcelino Montejo, Esteban Toon; 1870 Laureano Flores; 1877 Rafael Garcia, Erculeano Garcia /v Dutt 148 fn 60 /// 2 Jun 1882 Peña to OWT Mag. Celestino Peña [Sec to Gen Pech] claims Pech ultimatum [of 16 May 1882] concocted without Peña's knowledge during Gen Pech visit to San Antonio [Albion Isl] in early May 1882; singles out Albion Isl residents Manuel Jesus Castillo, Jose Santos Lopez, Jose Maria Sevilla, for instigating Pech /v Dutt 139 /CO 123/167 /// 8 Jun 1882 Exec Cl. Informed Gen Pech refused Lt Gov invitation to talks; orders arrest of Castillo and his associates; orders immediate prohibition of trade and communication with Icaiche /v Dutt 141 /CO 123/167 /// 6 Jul 1882 Lt Gov to Kimberley. Fears Castillo has tampered with witnesses for Crown, in particular, caused prime witness and loyal Sp resident, Francisco Escalante, to flee for fear of retribution /v Dutt 141 /CO 123/167 /// 13 Nov 1882 Castillo to Kimberley. Claims unjust trial /v Dutt 144 /CO 123/168 /// May 1883 Castillo associates escape to Icaiche /v Dutt 146 /CO 123/170 [Lt Gov to Derby 31 Aug 1833] /// 23 Aug 1883 Lt Gov to Derby. Reports condition pardon of Castillo on recommendation of Sir Robert Harley; condition = joint bond with 2 sureties for $10,000, with approval of Messrs Mutrie & Currie of William Guild & Co as sureties, and detention in Belize T for 6 months /CO 123/170

NAME: Treaty of Belize
DESC: Administrator of Colony, Col Sec Henry Fowler, brokers Treaty of Peace between Yuc and Chan Santa Cruz, which ultimately falls apart
NON—SP 0: John Chuch, Gen José Cresencio Poot
PRESS: Belize Advertiser 3 31 2 = 19 Jan 1884 / Belize Advertiser 3 33 2 = 2 Feb 1884 / Colonial Guardian [Belize] 2 52 2 = 29 Dec 1883 / Colonial Guardian [Belize] 3 2 2 = 12 Jan 1884
NOTE: 30 Jan 1884 Poot to Fowler. States received copy of Treaty [for ratification], but that Gen Canto got drunk and insulted a Chan Santa Cruz representative while in Colony, on acct of which Poot refuses to ratify Treaty /R 118

NAME: Unofficial majority in Leg Cl

NOTE: 1880, 1890 Hon petition Eng Parl or HM Govt for representative Parl, but are denied /v Toussaint 119–196 /// See P. Ashdown, *Journal of Imperial and Commonwealth History* 9(1), "Sweet-Escott, Swayne and the Unofficial Majority in the Legislative Council of British Honduras 1904–1911" [1980] /v Moberg 360 /// Jan 1891 Belize T. Gov George Melville fills four vacant seats in Leg Co with official members ie civil servants, whereupon People's Committee charge Leg Co as unconsitutional /v Ashdown 62 /// Jul 1891 Belize T. Stevens Bros & Co v Collector of Customs in Sup Ct challenge constitutionality of all-official Leg Co / 15 Jul 1891 CJ C. J. Anderson rules in favour of Stevens Bros & Co /v Ashdown 63–64 /// 4 Sep 1891 Belize T. Gov calls public meeting, pleading for constitutional and political peace, but is informed People's Committee will accept nothing less than unofficial majority /v Ashdown 65 /// 21 Jan 1892 Belize T. Gov Alfred Moloney informs public Col Off granted appointed unofficial majority in Leg Co, whereupon celebration ensues /v Ashdown 66–67

NAME: Smallpox
DESC: Severe outbreak of smallpox or measles among Maya and other Amerindians in Altiplano region = W Guat or NW of Guat City
NOTE: Possibly measles rather than smallpox, or outbreak of > 1 illness, or possibly of unknown nature /v Lujan 2 329 /// Epidemic disease—perhaps smallpox, but the records are unclear—was introduced to Yucatán as early as 1517 by Sp soldiers on the initial expedition to mainland Mexico out of Cuba (12 [p. 19]). In the quarter century between initial contact and the establishment of a major Sp presence w the founding of Mérida in 1542, and Bacalar and Valladolid in 1544 (12, p. 31), the peninsula's native population may have declined fm at least 800,000 (a conservative estimate) to about 250,000 (12, pp. 36 and 13, p. 212). [12 = I. Clendinnen, *Ambivalent Conquests: Maya and Spaniard in Yuc, 1517–1570* [Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, 1987] / 13 = N. M. Farriss, *Maya Society under Colonial Rule: The Collective Enterprise of Survival* [Princeton, Princeton University Press, 1984]] /v Graham F 1256

NAME: Casas—Maldonado Pact
DESC: Interim Governor of Guat Alonso de Maldonado secretly authorises the non-military conquest or reduction of Indians in Tierra de Guerra = Tezulutlán = Vera Paz by Dominican Frays Bartolomé de las Casas, Rodrigo de Ladrada, Pedro de Angulo, Luis Cáncer
SP: Gov Alonso de Maldonado, Fr Bartolomé de las Casas, Fr Rodrigo de Ladrada, Fr Pedro de Angulo, Fr Luis Cáncer
VIA: Lujan 2 627–628 / Soza xxx = ed 2 vol 2 p 429 / Rubio G 81–82
NOTE: See Verapaz map in Lujan 2 628 /// 1539 Maldonado a Carlos V. Ya algunos indios principales de aquella tierra que está de guerra [Vera Paz] habían [han?] venido a hablar con los padres [Dominican Frays las Casas, etc] / indios principales possibly or likely fm Cobán [Guat] /xxx /v Lujan 2 630 /// 1539 Aud of Mex confirms Casas—Maldonado Pact / 1540 Sp Council of Indies confirms or ratifies Aud of Mexico's 1539 confirmation of Casas—Maldonado Pact /v Lujan 2 631 /// 1544–1545 Vera Paz. Eight Dominican Frays inc Luis Cáncer reduce Indians near Coban [Guat] to Patal, Jatic [Tactic?], Chamelco, Tucurú / 1547 Tierra de Guerra = Tezulutlán renamed Vera Paz by Real Cédula /v Lujan 2 632 /// Late 1547 Golfo Dulce. Non-Dominicans est Nueva Sevilla, in contravention of Reales Cédulas prohibiting non-Dominican Sp fm entering Vera Paz, upon which [Dominican] Fr Tomás Casillas requests Aud of Guat, Pres Alonso López de Cerrato, enforce prohibition of Sp in Vera Paz, finally resolved in 1548 by military intervention lead by Ramírez de Quiñones against Nueva Sevilla /v Lujan 2 632–633 /v Zamora 175 /Fuentes 2 321–329 /// 1562 Pres Landecho est [non-Dominican] alcaldía mayor in Vera Paz, and imposes first tributes on Indian residents /v Lujan 2 634 /// 1550–1552 Golfo Dulce. Dominican Fray Domingo Vico reduces Chol Indians to Chol towns of Xocoló and Polochic, and to Poqomchi' towns of Tucurú and Tamahú / 1568 E Verapaz [Golfo Dulce?]. Indian reducción by [non-Dominican] Alcalde Mayor Casadavante / 1562–1581 Verapaz, N of Río Cahabón. First contact of Dominicans with Manche or Manche Chol Indians during Bishopric of Fr Tomás de Cárdenas, but suspended shortly thereafter / 1590s Verapaz. Fr Pedro Martínez, Fr Juan de Esquerra, Bishop Fernández Rosillo, Alcalde Mayor Fernández Parea, Pres Alonso Criado de Castilla recontact Manche or Manche Chol Indians / 1603–1604 Verapaz. Fr Juan de Esguerra, Fr Salvador Cipriano reduce Manche Chol Indians in Cucul and 6 other Manche towns; Frays Alejo de Montes, Bartolomé de Plaza join thereafter / c 1618 Verapaz. Frays Gabriel Salazar, Francisco Morán and 4 others continue reducciones of Manche Chol Indians / 1631 Verapaz. Alcalde Mayor Martín Alfonso Tovilla, Fr Morán establish villa Toro de Acuña in Mache Chol territory, to help defend against Itza and Mopan adversaries, which is thereafter attacked, along with San Miguel Manché, both of which are abandoned in favour of Cahabón [Río?] / 1630s–1671 Verapaz. Vars Dominican frays and alcaldes mayores attempt to reduce Chol or Manche Chol Mayans, without success / 1672–1673 Verapaz. Frays José Delgado, Francisco Gallegos, and others successfully reduce Chol or Manche Chol Mayans, but in 1677 these reducción towns are abandoned / 1685 Fr Agustín Cano and Fr José Delgado attempt reducción of Chol or Manche Chol Mayans, but fall ill shortly thereafter / 1689 Frays Delgado and Cano reduce Chol or Manche Chol Indians to Chol town of Santa Cruz, near Rabinal [Verapaz?] / 1695–1696 Further reducción of Chol or Manche Chol /v Lujan 2 636–637

NAME: Logwood licensed
DESC: Proclamation prohibiting importation of logwood except under licence
NOTE: 9 Dec 1605 [Lon]. George Earl of Dunbar granted all duties on logwood, blockwood, &c. /CSPD Jas 1 vol 17 no xxx [December, 1605] / 1 Jul 1607 [Lon]. Commission to Ld Treasurer Salisbury, for new tax on every cwt. of logwood and other prohibited dyeing woods / 21 Sep 1607 [Lon]. Warrant for order to Officers of Ports, to demand duties on blockwood, logwood, and otherwoods imported for dyeing of cloths /CSPD Jas I vol 28 no xxx / 13 Jun 1608 Westminster. Warrant to pay Earl of Dunbar £4,000 in compensation of imposition laid upon logwood, Brazil wood, &c., which was formerly granted him in lieu of a patent for the sole manufacture of logwood, revoked by Parl /CSPD Jas 1 vol 34 no xxx / 1 Jul 1608 [Lon]. Commission to Earl of Salisbury to charge duty on logwood and other prohibited dyeing woods /CSPD Jas 1 vol 35 no xxx / 15 Jul 1608 Lon. Chamberlain to Carleton. Informs Earl of Dunbar has £2,000 in lieu of his patent for logwood. /CSPD Jas 1 vol 35 no 22 / 21 Oct 1608 Whitehall. Council to Sir Hen Lee [Lord Mayor and Recorder of Lon]. Require them to examine a project for fixing colours dyed with logwood, encloses petition for a grant of patent or monopoly of sole import and sale of logwood /CSPD Jas I vol 37 no 24 /CSPD Jas 1 addenda vol 39 no 62 /CSPD Jas 1 addenda vol xxx no xxx / 19 Jul 1615 Westminster. Grant to Rich. Giles of Lon office of seizing and burning all logwood and deceitful dyeing woods brought into Lon /CSPD Jas 1 vol 81 no xxx / 21 Nov 1615 Whitehall. Earl of Suffolk to Rich. Gyles, waiter for prohibited woods. To permit Marmaduke Peckett, merchant of Lon, transport a ton of Log consigned him by mistake /CSPD Jas 1 vol 83 no xxx / 22 Nov 1616 [Lon]. Grant to Rich. Gyles and John Wilson of office of Waiter, to search out and seize logwood, &c., for life /CSPD Jas 1 vol 89 no xxx / Jun 1618 [Lon]. Petition of Thos. Colbert, mariner, to Council, for restoration of logwood imported by him when ignorant of prohibition against logwood; promises to transport and sell it abroad /CSPD Jas 1 vol 97 no 139 / 29 Feb 1620 Whitehall. Proc prohibiting general import of logwood, but permitting Sir Thos. Compton to import 50 tons yearly, to be used in dyeing mean commodities only. All other logwood imported to be seized, half burnt, and other half delivered, for 6l. per ton, to Sir Thos. Compton. /CSPD Jas 1 vol 112 / 25 Jul 1620 Westminster. Commission to Ld Mayor of Lon, Master of Wards and others, to examine and discover abuses in importing of logwood, contrary to Proc and to Sir Thos. Compton's patent, and to punish offenders /CSPD Jas 1 vol 116 / 2 May 1621 [Lon]. Petition of Wardens, &c. of Dyer's Co. to House of Commons against licence granted to Sir Thos Compton to import 50 tons of logwood, the colour being deceitful, and much more imported on the pretext of these 50 tons /CSPD Jas 1 addenda vol 42 no 49 / 29 Aug 1621 Westminster. King to Council. To consider means for restraining importation of logwood, because proposals for its suppresion being brought before Parl, it is feared that during the interim of its sittings, large quantities may be brought in and secreted. It is to be seized, and all destroyed, except 6l. worth per ton, reserved for seizer /CSPD Jas 1 vol 122 no 96 / 20 Feb 1622 [Lon]. Dyer's Co found logwood in house of Daniel Tibergen and Peter Cozie, both aliens, but on Company’s trying to seize the logwood, the aliens’ wife and servants prevented it /CSPD Jas 1 vol 127 no 114 / 28 Apr 1622 [Lon]. King to Mayor, Recorder and Justices of Lon, &c. To seize some parcels of indigo, logwood, and other prohibited commodities now concealed in Lon, which he bestows upon Duke of Lenox, on condition of his exporting them /CSPD Jas 1 vol 129 no 67 / 28 May 1622 Inner Temple [Lon]. Sir Thos. Coventry and Sir Robt. Heath to Council. Send draft letter of assistance for patentee for suppressing logwood, ask whether legal and agreeable to precedent /CSPD Jas 1 vol 130 no 118 / 24 Jun 1622 [Lon]. Council to all Mayors, Justices, Admiralty and Custom House Officers. To assist Sir Thos. Compton in executing his patent for searching for and seizing logwood, which is forbidden to be used in dyeing /CSPD Jas 1 vol 131 no 65 / Mar 1625 [Lon]. Licence to Sir Thos Compton to import yearly 50 tons Log for 21 years, to be used in colouring haberdashers' wares, and not in dyeing cloth, reserving to HM 50l. per annum /CSPD Chas 1 vol 1 no 14 /CSPD Chas 1 vol 14 no 1–2 / 21 Jul 1628 [Lon]. Grant to Mary Countess of Buckingham of 108 tons Log, brought in among HM reprisal goods, in consideration whereof she surrenders letters patent heretofore made to Sir Thomas Compton, her late husband, of which term [21 yrs] 12 years are unexpired /CSPD Chas 1 vol 110 / 20 Apr 1635 [Lon]. Petition of Robt. Earl of Ancram to King. HM bestowed on petitioner the licence to import 50 tons logwood, whereupon petitioner contracted with William Wall, merchant of Lon, for importation of Log. Wall seeks to defeat petitioner of his contract, has raised himself a great estate by unlawful dealing in Log eg c 4 yrs ago Wall deceitfully imported 400 tons Log. Petitioner prays Wall be punished by Star Chamber /CSPD Chas 1 vol 287 no 11 /CSPD Chas 1 vol 380 no 70 /CSPD Chas 1 vol 391 no 124 / 12 Jan 1638 Whitehall. Order of Council on petition of John Tanner, merchant, who showed that c 18 months since the patentees for logwood contracted with him to bring in Log for his use, upon which petitioner got 12 tons fm Canary Islands to Lon, which is now seized upon pretence of some contentions between the Earl of Ancram and the patentees, who now leave the petitioner in this trouble. Desires leave to transport these, and additional 8 tons Log now arrived at Downs, into foreign parts. Ordered copies be delivered to Earl of Ancram and patentees /CSPD Chas 1 vol 378 no 62 /CSPD Chas 1 vol 379 no 15 / 4 May 1638 Inner Star Chamber [Lon]. Order of Council on petition of Martin Bradgate, merchant of Lon, praying he be allowed to transport 600 quintals of Log fm Canary Isl /CSPD Chas 1 vol 389 no 43–45 / 26 Mar 1639 [Lon]. Petition of Sir Richd. Titchborne to King. Five yrs since YM granted to Thomas Travers and Thomas Sara liberty to import yearly 50 tons of Log alias blockwood, with full power to seize all other Log imported contrary to law, for term of 21 yrs, paying Crown rent of 50l., which said patentees' names were only used in trust for petitioner and Sir Nicholas Fortescue, since deceased. That John Langston, porter of the Tower, contracted with petitioner to pay 400l. for his said grant, but now refuses to stand his bargain, for want of which petitioner is likely to be prejudiced 1,000l. Prays reference to Lord Privy Seal and Sec. Windebank. /CSPD Chas 1 vol 415 / 23 Nov 1640 [Lon]. List of patents under debate in Parl inc [Capt Crispe’s] patent for importation of 50 tons of logwood /CSPD Chas 1 vol 472 no 16 /CSPD Chas 1 vol 484 no 26 /v Socolow 478

NAME: Bu cruise for prizes
DESC: Buccaneers or privateers cruise off Yuc, Hon, Sp Hon, and likely raid various coastal settlements, after raiding Campeachy and en route to raid Truxillo and Granada
PLACE: Campeachy, Laguna de Terminos, Sisal, Cape Catoche, xxx, Roatan, Truxillo, Cape Gracias a Dios, Granada
NON—SP 0: Capt John Morris, Capt David Martien, Capt Henry Morgan, Capt Jacob Fackman, Capt Freeman 200 men
NOTE: Late 1664 Capt Fackman joins John Morris, David Martien, Henry Morgan, Capt Freeman in sm expedition against Sp in Gulf of Mex, possibly while cruising near Yuc [after Sacking of Campeachy in early 1663], and possibly as reprisal for Aug 1664 probes against Eng loggers in Laguna de Terminos by Mateo Alonso de Huidobro / Jan 1665 Jam. Capts Morries, Martien, Morgan, Fackman and Freeman with a few vessels and 200 men sail for Campeachy / 19 Feb–19 Mar 1665 Capts seize Sp frigate in Campeachy, possibly sack Santa María de la Frontera [hamlet on Grijalva R mouth], sack Villahermosa de Tabasco [50 miles up Grijalva R], while 3 Sp Frigs 270 men sent fm Campeachy by Lt-Gov Antonio Maldonado de Aldana seize their ships at River's mouth and crew them with 300 militiamen under Capt José Aldana, which force thereafter repels the buccaneers / Summer 1665 Buccaneers reach Roatan to water after having hugged Yuc coast [inc Hon?], and thereafter assault Truxillo, and continue to Cape Gracias a Dios and Mos Shore, where they hire Mos for surprise raid on Granada [Nicaragua] on 29 Jun 1665 / Possibly see Dudley Pope, *Henry Morgan's Way: The Biography of Sir Henry Morgan, 1635–1684* [Lon, Secker & Warburg, 1977] / sn, *Interesting Tracts Relating to the Island of Jamaica* [St. Jago de la Vega, Lewis, Lunan & Jones, 1800] / Juan Juárez Moreno, *Piratas y corsarios en Veracruz y Campeachy* [Seville, Escuela de Estudios Hispano-americanos, 1972] /v Marley P 1 137–139 /// Possibly see 1665 Sto Tomás de Castilla, Granada attacked by Pir / 1665 Granada attacked by John Davis /v Lujan 2 472, 828

NAME: Capt Coxon prize
DESC: Capt John Coxon captures a Spanish merchantman laden with indigo
NOTE: Summer 1679 Capt Coxon sails towards Bay of Honduras [Hon?] / late Oct 1670 Jam. There has been lately taken from the Spaniards by Coxon, Bartholomew Sharpe, Bothing, and Hawkins [Richard Sawkins?] with their crew, 500 chests of indigo, a great quantity of cacao, cochineal, tortoise shell, money, and plate. Much is brought into this country already, and the rest expected. / Early Nov 1679 Jam. Lord Carlisle instructs HMS Hunter to arrest any rogue privateers attempting to land Sp indigo / Late Dec 1679 Port Morant [Jam]. Capts Cornelius Essex, Sharpe, Robert Allison, Thomas Magott agree to unite under Capt Coxon's leadership for assault on Portobello, citing outdated Fr and Eng commissions, inc let-passes fm Lord Carlisle to "go into the Bay of Honduras to cut logwood” /xxx /v Marley P 1 90, 127 /// See Gilbert M. Joseph, *Terrae Incognitae* 12(sn), "John Coxon and the Role of Buccaneering in the Settlement of the Yuc Colonial Frontier" [1980], 65–84 /v Latimer 308 no 49 /// Possibly see 1679 Bodegas del Golfo [Lake Izabal?] attacked by Pir /v Lujan 2 108 /// Possibly see 30 Jul 1679 Bodegas [Golfo Dulce] Alvarado de Villacreces Cueva y Guzmán a Pres de Guat. Informs Bodegas in Golfo Dulce sacked on 28 Jul 1679 by pirates in 7 canoes, who detained and kidnapped residents, and took 1 Balandra, 1 Barco luengo, 2 Lanchas, 800 t 1000 botijas de vino, 700 t 800 cajones de tinta, 16 t 20 petacas de pan and some olive oil /v Rodriguez C 33–35 /GUATEMALA,280 [Villacreces Cueva y Guzmán a Sierra a 30 jul 1679 / Testimoniado por Mantúfar a 1 ago 1679 / Alvarado a Pres a 2 ago 1679 / Arosemena a Pres a 4 ago 1679 / Pres al Rey a 6 abr 1680]

NAME: Capt Oxe marooned
DESC: Capt Robert Oxe and 8 of his men are marooned at Turneffe by Sp Guarda Costa, after which they are relieved by xxx
SP: Capt Pedro de Castro, Capt Juan Corso 2 GC
NOTE: > 16 May 1680 Capt Oxe sails away fm Bay of Campeachy in the Laurel, 35 tonnes, to "the Cays of Yuc for water" [Cozumel?], is then surprised by Sp GC, 2 of his men killed, Capt Oxe and remaining crew [≥ 8 men] put in canoe and thereafter land in Turneffe; are relieved 15 days later / Late 1680 Capt Oxe arrives at Port Royal /v Marley P 1 300

NAME: Attack on Veracruz
DESC: Laurens de Graaf, Nicholas van Hoorn and Michel de Grammont sack and ransom Veracruz
PLACE: Roatan, Veracruz, Isla de Sacrificios, Isla Mujeres
SP: Gov Luis Bartolomé de Córdova y Zúñiga, Adm Diego Fernández de Zaldívar, John Murphy, Mateo Alonso de Huidobro, Pedro Estrada
NON—SP 0: Laurens de Graaf, Lt Michiel Andrieszoon, Nicholas van Hoorn, Michel de Grammont, Jacob Hall, Jean Toccard 5 Ships 8 Sloops c 1300 men
NOTE: 1682 Hon [Sp Hon?] Fr Capt Blot and Capt Jan "Jantje" Willems sail to Honduras fm Cayman Islands in order to join 1683 Attack on Veracruz /v Marley P 1 49 /// Feb 1683 Petit-Goâve. Fr Gov grants letter of reprisal against Sp to Capt Nikolaas van Hoorn, who sails with Sieur de Grammont towards Central America [Hon?] to find Capt Graaf and Michiel Andrieszoon who were reputedly lying there with "two great ships, a bark, a sloop ... and 500 men" / xxx [Bay of Honduras] 2 large Sp merchantmen, Nuestra Señora de Consolación and Nuestra Señora de Regla, seized by Capt Graaf aboard his flagship Francesa; Capt Hoorn seizes 2 unladen [Sp] vessels, and disembarks [in Sp Hon] in search of indigo being brought to port / 7 Apr 1683 Roatan. Capt Graaf holds huge gathering of pirates, inc Capts Grammont and Hoorn, to propose assault against Veracruz; pirates agree, after which Capt Graaf sails northwards in Nuestra Señora de Regla and 1 other Sp prize [of Jan Willems], followed by fleet of 3 Ships 8 Sloops / 17 May–mid Jun 1683 Veracruz. Buccaneers take Veracruz, ransack it for 4 days, torture vars residents and move them to Isla de Sacrificios [where Graaf duels Hoorn], demand ransom for Veracruz fm Mexico City, which is received [= or in addition to 1,500 slaves], when Adm Diego Fernández de Zaldívar sights but does not pursue them / Late Jun 1683 Isla Mujeres. Buccaneers partition booty and go their separate ways /v Marley P 1 100–101 /// See David F. Marley, *Sack of Veracruz: The Great Pirate Raid of 1683* [Windsor, Ont. Netherlandic Press, 1993] /// Possibly see 1683 Bodegas del Golfo Dulce, and Verapaz via Río Polochic raided or attacked by Dutch pirate Juan Zanques /v Lujan 2 108

NAME: xxx
DESC: Dutch pirates, buccaneers or privateers raid or assault Bodegas del Golfo [Lake Izabal = Golfo Dulce] or Castillo de San Felipe [Golfo Dulce]
NOTE: Dec 1683. Du pirate Zanques enters Lake Izabal = Golfo Dulce, reaches Bodegas, enters R Polochic to Verapaz, reaches Turucub where they kidnap Indian Gaspar Quema and his wife, and retire /v Rodriguez C 40–41 /GUATEMALA,280

NAME: xxx
DESC: Dutch pirates, buccaneers or privateers raid or assault Bodegas del Golfo [Lake Izabal = Golfo Dulce] or Castillo de San Felipe [Golfo Dulce]
NON—SP 0: Juan Zanques 1 Balandra some PA 400 men inc Mos allies

NAME: Cano reductions
DESC: Fray Cano leads reducción efforts in Manche Chol area
NOTE: 1689 Some or vars recently reduced Manche Chol reducción settlements fall apart /v Bolland F 18 /// Possibly see [1686–1699 Guat] Confina este extendido territorio [de la Provincia del Golfo Dulce] por la parte de Medio-día de su asiento, y situación con el corregimiento de Cazabastlán; por el Sudoeste hasta el Poniente con la Provincia de Varapaz, y deste rumbo al Noroeste con gran región de indios infieles; y por la parte que mira al Septentrión con las riveras del Mar del Norte; mas por lo que mira al Leste confina con la gran Provincia de Honduras, sin que entre estos confines se le interponga otro alguno. /Fuentes 1 xiv–xx, 421 /Fuentes 2 290

NAME: Sack of Campeachy
DESC: Capt de Graaf and Grammont lead assault on Campeachy
SP: Felipe de la Barrera y Villegas, Capt Cristóbal Martínez de Acevedo, Gov Juan Bruno de Téllez de Guzmán, Adm Andrés de Ochoa y Zárate
NON—SP 0: Capt de Graaf, Capt Grammon, Capt Willems, Capt Andrieszoon, George Bannister, Pierre Bot 10 Ships 6 Sloops 17 PA 700 men
NON—SP 1: Capt David Mitchell of HMS Ruby
NOTE: Jan 1685 Curaçao. Gov refuses buccaneers under de Graaf entry, after which they head to Hon [Sp Hon?] to plan attacks on Sp; is joined by more buccaneers inc Andrieszoon, Grammont, Willems, and up to 20 other Capts / Jun 1685 Hon or Sp Hon. Graaf and Grammont 6 Ships 6 Sloops 17 PA 4 sm Vessels 700 men towards Cape Catoche / 6 Jul–Sep 1685 Campeachy taken /v Latimer 252–255 /// Possibly see 1685 Castillo de San Felipe attacked by Pirate Juan Zanques /v Lujan 2 108 /// Possibly see 1685 Golfo Dulce. Vars parties of pirates enter R Dulce, R Montague /v Zamora 178 /// Possibly see 1685 Golfo Dulce. Juan Zanques and his men enter Golfo Dulce, Bodegas, Verapaz, reach Lunrub and kidnap an Indian /v Rodriguez C 47 /GUATEMALA,280 [Pres a Rey a 27 feb 1685] /// 1685 Guat. Pir enter Golfo Dulce in 21 PA, head to Verapaz /v Garcia P 2 121 /// 1684–1685 Old R. Nicholas van Horn, Dutch buccaneer, spends sm months logging at Hon, then leads or participates in 1685 Sack of Campeachy /v Joseph C 74–76 /1163 CSPC 11 [Jul 1683] /339 CSPC 12 [Aug 1685] /Blathwayt vol 25 [Molesworth to Blathwayt 4 May 1686]

NAME: Capt Willems prize
DESC: Capts Jan Willems and Jacob Evertsen surprise Sp ship in Bay of Honduras
NON—SP 0: Capt Jan Willems, Capt Jacob Evertsen 1 Ship 1 Bark 1 Sloop c 150 men
NOTE: Feb 1688 Albemarle reports "that the pirates Yankey [Willems] and Jacobs have fallen upon a great Sp ship in the Bay of Honduras called the Hulk [an urca], and that they had been in sight of her twelve hours. If Yankey failed in this attempt he is ruined, for it is said that he was very ill provided before." / Apr 1688 Albemarle confirms buccaneers fought and took the Sp ship "in the port of Cavana", but [shortly?] thereafter died / Late Summer 1688 NE. Capt Peterson appears with "the remainder of Yankey's and Jacob's company" /v Marley P 2 588–589 /// Possibly see 1688 Pres of Guat Jacinto Barrios Leal meets with Pirates in Puerto Caballos, but escapes / 1688 Bodegas del Golfo, Olancho raided or attacked by Pir /v Lujan 2 108, 472 /// Possibly see 17 Nov 1688 Bodegas [Golfo Dulce]. Incoming Pres of Guat Barrios Leal w 25 men fm Capt Juan Tomás Miluti meet Pir in 1 Frig 1 Barca, who make off w the President's 2 Barcas /v Rodriguez C 50 /v Garcia P 2 97–98 /// Possibly see 29 Sep 1688 Pres of Guat to Sp King. Informs Pir enter Valley of Truxillo by R Aguan, land 400 men, raid Truxillo, and attempt but fail to raid Olancho, abduct fm Truxillo a teniente de gobernador, 22 women, and others, and demand 5,000 pesos for their delivery /v Garcia P 2 121

NAME: xxx
DESC: Sp military campaigns against Manche Chol
NOTE: ≥ 1689 Sp forcibly resettle Manche Chol to Guat highlands, where Chol are absorbed by Kekchi Mayans /v Bolland F 18

NAME: xnp
DESC: Pirates or buccaneers raid or assault Amatique
NOTE: [1691 Guat] [el pueblo de] *Amatique*, que llegara hasta treinta y cinco [vecinos] ... y por su número de vecinos al de ciento, y cuarenta habitadores ... en la contemplación de sus servicios [indios de Amatique = vigías] y buen celo, siendo asaltado por interpresa este pueblo de *Amatique* por el año pasado de 1690. Sin ejemplar á este tiempo en este pueblo, y hechos prisioneros los indios varones que en él halló el pirata, y conducidos á sus embarcaciones, pidió por su rescate una buena cantidad de maíces, que se le mandó dar muy promptamente por la libertad de los prisioneros, con cuyo aliento y experiencia perseveran más finos y leales en semejantes empleos [de vigía]. /Fuentes 2 296–297

NOTE: Possibly see 1736 SSC report re logwood in Elizabeth Donnan, *Documents Illustrative of the History of the Slave Trade to America*, 4 vols [Washington, sn, 1930–1935], vol 2 p 459 /v Socolow 490 /// 3 Jan 1719 Vera Cruz. Sp real orden to seize all SSC property reaches Vera Cruz, upon which 1,251 pesos of company property are seized at Campeachy /v Sorsby T 93–96 /// Apr 1735 Campeachy. Spain orders SSC to end slave sales at Campeachy, possibly in attempt to stem illegal cutting and export of logwood along Yuc fm Hon to Campeachy / Oct 1738 Campeachy. SSC leaves /U Mich Shelburne Papers vol 43 f 265 [Nasmyth to Burrell 14 Jul 1736] /INDIFERENTE,2792 [Geraldino a Patiño a 23 ago 1736] /INDIFERENTE,2851 [sn a Geraldino a 23 abr 1736 / Tyrry a Torrenueva a 26 feb 1736] /v Sorsby T 211 /// See partial SSC Campeachy shipping to 1739 in Sorsby T 258–423

NAME: Long-distance Mos raids
DESC: Mosquito and zambo men raid or attack Olancho
NOTE: 1729 Sp Hon. Mos, possibly w Bay or Shoremen, abduct vars residents to trade as slaves w Jam merchants / 1730 Olancho. 30 residents abducted /v Palma 49 /// Possibly see [< Nov 1729 Sp Hon] En la Gazeta mensual de Guat de noviembre de [1]729, se refiere que los zambos habian hecho algunos prisioneros en la costa de Honduras /v Garcia P 2 163 /// [30 Apr 1730 Olancho] En la [Gazeta de Guat] de mayo del mismo año [1]730 se lée lo siguiente. El dia 11 [mayo?] convocó el M. ilustre señor presidente junta de guerra, y en ella se leyeron las cartas del governador de Honduras, y del alcalde mayor de Tegucigalpa, quienes avisan la intempestiva, cuanto irremediable invasion, que los bárbaros mosquitos ejecutaron el dia 30 de abril en el valle de Olancho, llevándose 36 personas; … Las cartas de Comayagua llegaron, y noticia que el número [de mosquitos] fué de 180 en cuatro compañías comandadas por los ingleses, y que aunque el teniente de governador de Olancho hizo gente y marchó en su alcance, no logró el rescate de los prisioneros, sino solo los deudos el de una española por cien pesos./v Garcia P 2 164–165

NAME: Fortaleza de San Fernando built
DESC: Fortaleza or Castillo de San Fernando de Omoa built in port of Omoa
NOTE: 1752–1756 Omoa. [Provisional fort] El Real built /v Zackrison 57–58 /// Dating of start of construction given variously as 1756, 1759, 1768 /xxx /// Jun 1757 Omoa. Rock for foundation of fort or Castillo secured / 12 Nov 1758 Omoa. Foundation of fort completed /v Zackrison 60 /// 18 Sep 1759 Omoa. Finalised plans for fort finally arrive /v Zackrison 62 /// 1775 Omoa. Fort completed /v Zackrison 91, 107

DESC: Coromantee slave revolt in Jam led by General Tacky
NON—SP 1: Zackary Bayly, Lt Gov Henry Moore
NOTE: See 1760 Jam map in Craton 128 / ≥ Oct 1761 Jam. ≥ 500 rebel slaves transported out of Jam, mostly to Hon /v Craton 138 /Long 2 462

NAME: Mahogany trade
DESC: Brig Inflexible enters Kingston from Hon, carrying Honduras Mahogany, possibly first such shipment
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Location laws codified
DESC: Pub Mtg codify customary location ie logging works laws, possibly first instance in Hon
NOTE: 10 Apr 1765 St. George's. [Resolved] First–When a person finds a spot of Log unoccupied, and builds his hutt, that spot shall be deemed his property; and no person shall presume to cutt or fall a tree, or grub a stump, within less than one thousand paces or yards of his Hutt, to be continued on each side of said hutt, with the course of the river or creek on both sides; and whatever person shall presume, after the limits are ascertained, to enter within those limits, shall, on proof thereof, on oath before one Justice, forfeit double the value of the wood cut, and be obliged to ship it on board of such ship or vessel as the proprietor of the wood shall appoint to receive it. Second–That no Inhabitant whatever shall occupy two works at any one time in any one River. Third–That no inhabitant shall claim a double portion of logwood works, under pretence of a partner, except that partner is, and deemed ot be, an inhabitant of the Bay. /v Bolland F 29 /CO 123/5 /Laws 1810 xxx /// 6 May 1766 St. George's. [Resolved] The method of measuring logwood works shall be a straight line of two thousand yards or paces, to be begun and ended at the rivers side, and that the division line be run parallel [perpendicular] to the general course of the River; and that no logwood work shall be deemed to be evacuated as long as the owner lives in the Bay, except he occupy some other work in the same river. /v Bolland F 30 /CO 123/5 [Minutes 6 May 1766] /Laws 1810 xxx /// 25 Jul 1787, 4 Aug 1787 Belize T. Location laws amended /v Bolland L 14–17

NAME: King's Advocate’s Report
DESC: King's Advocate Sir James Marriott concludes Hon settlers are under "no Jurisdiction at all" of England nor Spain, and "have a *natural* right to form themselves by an original compact into any model of government"
NOTE: See CO 137/57/2 [Hon inhabitants to sn 2 Jun 1745] /v Gould 773

NAME: Importation Act
DESC: English Parliament pass Importation Act 1771, abolishing duty on wood imported to England fm Hon and all foreign possessions in Americas
NOTE: 11 Sep 1770 Lon. HM Customs rules Hon Mah subject to duty on importation to England given that Hon is Sp territory /T 1/475 f 404 [Memorial 11 Sep 1770] /v Bowett 158 /// See BT 6/50 [Memorial to Sidney 24 Dec 1784] /v Bowett 159

NAME: Long-distance Mos raids
DESC: Mosquito or zambo men raid or attack Río Ulúa
NOTE: El presidente Mayorga, en consulta de 30 de octubre de [1]773, muestra que continuaban en este tiempo las invasiones é insultos de los zambos mosquitos: pues recibe aviso del comandante de Omoa, que habiendo éstos llegado á la boca del rio de Ulúa donde estaba una vigía nuestra de cuatro índios tributarios, matando uno y llevando prisioneros los tres restantes, salió armada la piragua Sta. Rosalia á cargo del piloto don Joseph Antonio Martinez con veinte hombres de tripulacion, que siguiendo su rumbo costa á costa á Ulúa, puerto de Sal, y Triunfo de la Cruz sin encontrar nada, prosiguiendo á la barra del rio de Lean, vió dice, cuatro casa ó ranchos, y en ellos cosa de 25 á 30 hombres, no pudiendo distinguir, si eran zambos ó ingleses, y hubo de parte á parte un vivo fuego que empezaron los contrarios, empañándose la piragua á la entrada del rio donde baró; y habiendo hecho huir aquella gente descuadernada en una piragua y un bote, en que le parece embarcaron tercios, siguió el resto de seis ú ocho hombres, que quedaron en las casas haciendo mucho fuego á los nuestros al abrigo de troncos y árboles, matando al patron Pedro Martir de un balazo, y se retiró Martinez ya escaso de municiones, y por no ser á propósito la piragua para dar caza, pareciéndole haber hecho destrozo en los contrarios. /v Garcia P 2 168

NAME: Lon agent est
DESC: Robert White appointed agent in Lon to HM Govt for inhabitants of the Bay of Honduras, possibly first foreign representative for Hon
NOTE: Possibly see MHS MS S-6.6 [Memo to Germain 9 Dec 1776] re secret plan for military campaign against Spain w Mos allies, believed author = Robert White ie former Bayman turned Lon agent for Hon /v Anderson M 243 fn 95

NAME: Pub Mtg restrict suffrage
DESC: Public Meeting further restrict suffrage by raising property qualification
NOTE: 10 Jun 1789 Property qualification set at J£ 65 /CO 123/12 [Regulations 10 Jun 1789] /v Bolland F 37

NAME: Pub Mtg restrict suffrage
DESC: Public Meeting further restrict suffrage, explicitly barring [free] people of colour from voting for Mags or Pub Mtg
NOTE: 23 Apr 1790 Belize T. [Resolved that] any person entitled to vote at elections for Magistrates for this Settlement ... must be possessed of a fixed Habitation or a Negro Slave or a Mahogany or Logwood work or visible property to the amount of Eighty Pounds Current money of Jam and that no person of colour was allowed to vote /CO 123/12 [Minutes 23 Apr 1790] /v Bolland F 37 /// 3 May 1790 Belize T. Mags elections held, Col Despard elected with unprecedented [in records] 203 of 250 votes /v Bolland F 38 /CO 123/9 /// [1790 Belize T.] Four defeated Mags complain about Despard's canvassing techniques, number of ineligible votes, and breadth of the franchise, complain about "ignorant turtlers ... men of colour, possessing no species of property or an fixed residence" voting for Despard, saying "There are not above 76 wood cutters of all descriptions in the Bay of Honduras, of whom, at least, Twenty hardly deserve that name, and about 40 White housekeepers, being traders and tradesmen, so that, in our opinion, there cannot be above 110 good voters in the Settlement; and on this principle ... few of Colonel Despard's friends, or even himself, would have been returned as Magistrates" /v Bolland F 38 /CO 123/13 [Acct by Bartlet et al] /// Possibly see 13 Aug 1793 Belize T. Fourteen Mos evacuees or families petition to be permitted to return to the Mos Shore, stating they were unable to support themselves by cutting wood or growing provisions and did not wish to be "half British Subjects as we are at present" /v Bolland F 40 /CO 137/92 [Petition to Pitt 13 Aug 1793]

NAME: Haitian Revolution
DESC: xnp
NOTE: 26 Nov 1791 Belize T. Fr ships carrying > 200 St Domingue revolutionaries arrive, but Pub Mtg decide "they should not be permitted to land so infectious a cargo" /v Bolland F 75 /CO 123/13 [Bartlet to Dyer, Allan & Co 26 Nov 1791] /// 1800 Belize T. Pub Mtg discuss "apprehension of internal convulsion and the horrors of St. Domingo" /v Bolland F 75 /v Burdon 1 282 /// 5 Apr 1807 Belize T. Louis Sovereign, Fr Black man, "was for some time confined in Gaol here, and not long since transported fm hence, as a suspicious character ... [he] committed no crime here, but was sent fm the settlement, merely on account of his being originally fm St. Domingo" /CO 123/17 [Hamilton to Mags 5 Apr 1807] /// 29 May 1809 Belize T. Concern expressed re "the evil disposition of the Non Commissioned Officers belonging to the 5th West India Regiment, among whom are several who commanded Companies of black Troops in St. Domingo" /CO 123/18 [Dyer to Cooke 29 May 1809] /v Bolland F 75–76

NAME: 1st WIR est
DESC: First West India Regiment commissioned
NOTE: 24 Apr—1 Sep 1795 Eight WIR commissioned, inc incorporation of Carolina Corps, est 1779, to 1st WIR /xxx /// Possibly see A. B. Ellis, *The History of the First West India Regiment* [Lon, Chapman and Hall, 1885] /// See Roger N. Buckley, *Slaves in Redcoats: The British West India Regiments, 1795–1815* [New Haven, Yale University Press, 1979] /v Anderson M 350 fn 102

NAME: Second Maroon War
DESC: xnp

NAME: Logging expanded
DESC: Logging extends south of Sibun R
NOTE: Though see lossy 1777 Washington Affair re Sherboon R /// ≤ 1799 Deep R logging begun / ≤ 1809 Stand Creek = important settlement "from whence considerable quantities of wood has been shipped, and HM Ships that come to Hon generally water there" /CO 123/18 [Barrow Remarks 1 May 1809] / ≤ 1806 Grande R [N of PG] logging begun /v Burdon 2 92 / ≤ 1814 Moho R [S of PG] settled /CO 123/23 [Smyth to Bathurst 24 May 1814] /v Burdon 2 167 / ≤ 1824 Sarstoon R settled or logging begun /v Humphreys 18 /FO 15/4 [Horton to Planta 23 Sep 1825] /v Bolland F 31

NAME: Jam Slave Law applied
DESC: Jamn Slave Law 1800 partially adopted in Hon, possibly first regulations upon slaves
NOTE: Possibly not inc criminal code eg 12 Nov 1813 Belize T. Slave tried for mrder of master "by a Court Martial composed of the Officers of Militia ... there being no criminal Code in force here by which so atrocious an offender could be tried & adequately punished" /v Bolland F 62 /CO 123/22 [Smyth to Bathurst 12 Nov 1813] /// c 1787 Belize T. Slave Ct est only "for the trial of Slaves for offences not amounting to felony" /v Bolland F 62 /CO 318/77 f 3 [Report 24 Feb 1829]

NAME: Arthur restricts Courts
DESC: Superintendent Arthur restricts powers of civil courts
NOTE: 1815 Belize T. Sup restrictions = criminal punishments only by fines, imprisonment or transportation, and civil authorities to have no jurisdiciton over military or naval personnel in civil nor criminal cases, though ancient customs of Hon otherwise to continue in force /v Bolland F 168 /v Dobson 121 /// 11 Jan 1817 Belize T. Sup repors a slave had "during the late Xmas made an attempt upon the life of one of the oldest Mags in the Country ... It is not probable that the inability of the Bench to proceed against offences of so serious a nature can be kept long a secret fm the lower orders of this extensive community, and the consequences are certainly to be dreaded when the Slave Population are apprized of it ... Crimes of this nature, which have been so frequent of late, will accumulate upon us very fast" /CO 123/26 [Arthur to Bathurst 11 Jan 1817] /v Bolland F 168–169 /// 1818 Belize T. Pub Mtg, with support of Sup Arthur, petition for authority in Hon to try murders / Jun 1819 Lon. Eng Parl pass Act for the Punishment of Certain Offences in the Bay of Hon /v Bolland F 169 /v Dobson 122

NAME: WIR veteran arrivals
DESC: 556 veterans of 2nd and 5th West India Regiments, and their families = 135 women and children, settle in Hon
CF: CO 123/26 [Arthur to Mags 18 Jun 1817 / Arthur to Bathurst 20 Nov 1817] / CO 123/27
NOTE: See Roger N. Buckley, *Slaves in Redcoats: The British West Indian Regiments, 1795–1815* [New Haven, Yale University Press, 1979], 136–139, Appendix D 156–157 /v Craton 364 no 15–16 /// 18 Jun 1817 Belize T. Informs "HM Govt have been pleased to determine on disbanding the 5th WIR, and to provide for five hundred of the Men by removing them to this Settlement where they are to receive Grants of Land proportioned to their means of cultivation, or to engage themselves in the service of Wood-Cutters, or other Inhabitants as they themselves prefer" /CO 123/26 [Arthur to Mags 18 Jun 1817] / 20 Nov 1817 Belize T. Reports that "in the Distribution of the Disbanded Soldiers of the 5th WIR the continuity of the situation decided me in giving grants of Land to a large proportion of them up the River Sibun, and in Manatee Lagoon" /CO 123/26 [Arthur to Bathurst 20 Nov 1817] / Feb 1818 Belize T. Reports men discharged fm 2nd WIR and 5th WIR at present are settled in Hon, total = 412 men, 59 women, 39 children / Oct 1818 Further 144 men, 22 women, 15 children arrive /CO 123/27 /v Bolland F 89 /// 14 Nov 1843 Stann Creek. WIR pensioners petition Sup Fancourt for redress after their plantations are destroyed by cattle of John Usher, who claimed their land through 'a very extensive Grant' fm Sup Macdonald /R 17 [Memorial to Fancourt 14 Nov 1843] / 30 Jul 1855 Belize T. [Keeper of Records re grants claimed by Sup Arthur to have been made to WIR pensioners south of Sibun R] I am informed that lands have been given to superannuated soldiers for the purposes of cultivation, but I cannot learn that such were given by deed /R 54 [Farquharson to Stevenson 30 Jul 1855] /v Bolland L 52 /// 6 Mar 1868 Belize T. [Gov Longden] I think it would be right also to confirm in their possession, by Crown Grants, without payment, the Lands now held by descendants of old soldiers ... of the 5th WIR ... to such, as did not engage themselves in Mah cutting, lands were assigned at Manate [Manatee Lagoon] ... Other soldiers fm the disbanded 7th WIR also received Lands at a place called after them, No. 7 Creek", Manate. It appears also to have been the custom of Col MacDonald, and, perhaps, other Sups, to grant to old military pensioners discharged in the Colony, permission to occupy lands and build houses thereon. To the descendants of all these old soldiers, who are now in actual possession of the plots of land ... I would suggest that I should be authorized to give Crown titles, without payment. The whole extent of the land occupeid is very small, but I think it would be a great hardship if it were sold (as is alleged in one instance to have been done) over the heads of the present occupiers to large proprietors /R 98 [Longden to Grant 6 Mar 1868] /v Bolland L 52–53 /// < 1869 WIR settlers unable to obtain freehold property on Manatee Lagoon, S of Sibun R / 6 Mar 1869 Belize T. Gov suggests he be authorised to give gratuitous Crown grants for plots of land in possession of WIR settlers /R 98 [Longden to Grand 6 Mar 1869] /v Bolland F 162"

NAME: Grant v Hyde
DESC: Mr Craig challenges lawfulness of Crown grant of land to George Hyde in Grand Ct, ultimately resulting in hung jury
NON—SP 0: Sup Cockburn, George Hyde, William Gentle, William Coffin
CF: R 6 [Cockburn to Goderich 8 Mar, 1 Aug 1831 / Cockburn to sn 19 Nov 1831 / Anderson to Glenelg 22 Apr 1836]
NOTE: Jan 1830 Belize T. Sup grants Mah work on Hondo to Hyde / Nov 1830 Belize T. Craig requests Hyde grant be cancelled, showing prior claim by bill of sale dated 1814, though Sup notes the grant was lawfully made and so not revocable /R 6 [Cockburn to Goderich 8 Mar 1831] / Jan 1831 Belize T. Craig sues Hyde in Grand Ct for "damage done by the Defendant in cutting Wood on and illegally keeping possession of the Plaintiff's Mahogany Work," upon which Sup seeks to preclude suit fm proceeding but is directed to not interfere, though suit results in hung jury /R 6 [Cockburn to Goderich 1 Aug 1831 / Cockburn to sn 19 Nov 1831] / 1836 Belize T. Craig withdraws suit /R 6 [Anderson to Glenelg 22 Apr 1836] /v Bolland F 43–44 /// Possibly see 30 Jul 1855 Belize T. As to the comparative merits of [land] titles by 'location' [ie Locations Laws] and titles by [Crown] 'grant', I [CJ Temple] should say that they are equally good /R 54 [Temple to Stevenson 30 Jul 1855] /v Bolland F 44 /// Possibly see Charles Craig, *Proceedings, &c., in the action, Craig versus Hyde : in the Grand Courts of the British Settlement at Honduras under the superintendance of His Excellency Francis Cockburn, Esquire, lieutenant colonel in the 2nd West India Regiment, &c., &c.* [Lon, Printed by Frederick Mason for Charles Craig, 1832] OCLC 506029195 Link: http://gw.worldcat.org.proxygw.wrlc.org/oclc/506029195

NAME: Bustillo rebellion
DESC: José Busillo obtains arms in Hon for rebellion against Guat
CF: AGCA B119.2 exp 57787 leg 2530 / AGCA B10.6 exp 3967 leg 182 f 5
NOTE: May 1832 Truxillo. Guat Govt forces, under Lt Col Francisco Ferrera, occupy [Bustillo allied ?] rebel-held Truxillo /v Palma 44 /AGCA B10.6 exp 3967 leg 182 f 5 /// 3 Jun 1833 Omoa Comandante a Pres. Informa "los morenos emigrados a las costas de Belice, incitados por los facciosos derrotados en 1832 pretenden atacar la plaza" /v Palma 44 /AGCA B10.6 exp 3990 leg 183 f 8 /// 1832 Punta Gorda [Hon]. Defeated Garifuna, allied w Bustillo, settle PG /v Palma 47 /AGCA B119.2 exp 57787 leg 2530 /AGCA B10.6 exp 3967 leg 182 f 5 /// See Azzo Ghidinelli, *Guat Indigena* 8(4), "Aspectos económicos de la cultura de los Caribes negros del Municipio de Livingston,” [1972], 71–140 /v Palma 84 /// 1835 Guat. Informes indican que los magistrados beliceños habían proclamado oficialmente los límites territoriales de su establecimiento, y que el Coronel Cockburn. había estimulado la colonización de las tierras localizadas entre los ríos Sibún y Sarstún, con aproximadamente 2,000 caribes hondureños que habían peleado con las fuerzas conservadoras invasoras de 1831–1832 / 30 Jan 1835 Guat. Chief of State of Guat in Rep of CA, Mariano Gálvez, petitions federal govt to protest Garifuna resettlement in Hon, w which federal Govt of CA complies /v Lujan 4 135

NAME: Gálvez land concessions
DESC: Chief of State in Rep of CA, Mariano Gálvez, makes several land concessions in or near Hon to various private British men
SP: Mariano Gálvez, Col John Galindo, Carlos Antonio Meany
CF: FO 252/15 [Chatfield to Palmerston 10 Oct 1834 / Chatfield to Cockburn 10 Oct 1834 / Chatfield to Cockburn 13 Oct 1834] / FO 15/14 [Chatfield to Backhouse 13 Oct 1834 / Chatfield to Palmerston 13 Oct 1834 / Chatfield to Palmerston 22 Oct 1834] / FO 252/8 [Cockburn to Chatfield 13 Sep 1834 / Cockburn to Chatfield 22 Nov 1834]
NOTE: See concessions map in Lujan 4 318 /// Early 1834 Guat. Bennett and Meany negotiate land grants in Chiquimula and Verapaz / 24 Mar 1834 Guat. Galindo granted land concession in Peten, though this is later conditionally granted to Eastern Coast Co in case of non-use by Galindo / Aug 1834 Guat. Gould, representing Eastern Coast Co, w Bennett, negotiate with Guat Govt for land concessions / 18 Aug 1834 Guat. Chief of State Gálvez grants two land concessions to Bennett and Eastern Coast Co in Chiquimula and Verapaz / 11 Sep 1834 Belize T. Sup Cockburn receives letter fm Galindo announcing intention to make use of his Peten land concession, after which Sup requests Royal Navy ships / 30 Sep 1834 Guat. News reaches Guat re belligerent statements by Magistrate Young, threatening Port of Izabal should Galindo settle Peten / Jan 1835 Guat. Bennett further granted land concession in Bay of [Sp] Hon inc Sto Tomás de Castilla /v Lujan 4 131 /// c mid-1836 Arrival of first shipload of British colonists /v Bethell 3 485 /// 8 Mar 1834 Guat Congress approve proposal by Juan Galindo to settle lands between Old and Hondo R /v Lujan 4 318 /// 16 Aug 1834 Guat Congress approve settlement contract w Eastern Coast Co / 19 Aug 1834 Guat Congress further grant Galindo concession to Eastern Coast Co in case of non-fulfilment by Galindo /v Lujan 4 319 /// 5 Nov 1834 Belize T. [Las autoridades de Belice] asentaron un reclamo formal [re Galindo land concession], por derecho de ocupación anterior a la Independencia de CA, de una frontera que iba del Río Hondo hacia el sur a través de las Cataratas de Garbutt al Río Sartún. Cualquier caoba talada más allá de estos límites y enviada a través de Belice pagaría el impuesto local establecido sobre madera de origen extranjero /v Lujan 4 320 /// Jul–Oct 1836 Golfo Dulce. 220 settlers sent by Eastern Coast Co to settle New Liverpool on banks of R Cahabón, and Santa Cruz on Lake Izabal, but disillusioned settlers mutiny and head to Belize T / c mid-1837 Verapaz. Eastern Coast Co's New Liverpool and Santa Cruz settlements practically abandoned /v Lujan 4 322–323 /Crowe xxx / Re New Liverpool see James Wood, *The Adventures, Sufferings and Observations of James Wood* [Lon, Simpkin & Marshall, 1840] /v Lujan 4 337 /// Apr 1840 Golfo Dulce. 68 settlers disembark to settle Eastern Coast Co's Abbottsville [on R Boca Nueva, near R Polochic] /v Lujan 4 326

NAME: Santa María–Calatrava Treaty
DESC: Sp–Mexican Treaty, wherein Spain recognise Mexico
SP: Miguel Santa María, José María Calatrava
NOTE: 11 Nov 1850 Stanley to Merivale. Mr. Villiers [HM Min at Madrid] renewed his application [to M. Martinez de la Rosa] on this matter [re GB sovereignty over Hon] early in 1836, when a Treaty for the recognition of Mexico was under consideration at Madrid. He requested that the Sp Govt, in order not to interfere with the British negoriations, would omit the question of Boundary in the project of Treaty with Mexico, as one in which Spain had no concern; and M. Mendizabal said that he would comply with Mr. Villiers' request. /CO 884/1/18 f 60 /// See Jorge Schiavon, Daniela Spencer & Mario Vásquez Olivera, *En busca de una nación soberana* [Mexico, CIDE-SRE, 2006], 157–200 /v Hoshino 45 fn 6

NAME: Crown Land fees
DESC: Fees for allotment of Crown Lands introduced on HM Govt prompt
CF: R 15 [Glenelg Circular 15 Sep 1838] / R 14 [Macdonald to Sec 9 Feb 1839]
VIA: Moberg C 28 / Bolland F 119–120 / Bolland L 58–60
NOTE: 15 Sep 1838 Lon. Sec directs passage of "Law for preventing the unauthorized occupation of Land,” among other laws deemed necessary after end of apprenticeship /R 15 [Glenelg Circular 15 Sep 1838] / 12 Nov 1838 Lon. Col Office circular "directing that grants of land are only to be made on payment of £1 per acre" /R 14 [Macdonald to Sec 9 Feb 1839] / 9 Feb 1839 Belize T. Sup urges Sec to allow him to continue "to act with regard to the disposal of land as my predecessors and myself have hitherto done ... by making free grants of land encouragement has been given to those disposed to cultivate the soild ... the permanent welfare of this place must mainly depend upon the rearing of colonial produce" /R 14 [Macdonald to Sec 9 Feb 1839] /v Bolland F 119 /// 22 Apr 1839 Lon. The argument which you have urged against the sale, in preference to the gratuitous donation of Lands in Hon, is, in substance, that the demand of a price for Land would discourage or prevent the extension of the cultivation of it. This opinion is however opposed to the universal experience which has been obtained in every other part of the Colonial Possessions of the Crown in which the same question has arisen. The effect of alienating the waste lands of hte Crown by a mere gift of them has always been in fact the same. It has tended to create indolent habits, to discourage labour for wages, and to leave large tracts of Territory in a wild & unimproved state. /R 15 [Normanby to Macdonald 22 Apr 1839] /v Bolland F 119–120 /// 1843 Belize T. Sup MacDonald issues two Notices, the effect of which were to make free grants of Crown land, upon which Sec instructs succeeding Sup [Fancourt] that the gratuitous alienation ... of the Public Lands which is contemplated by these Notices ... is contrary to the Instructions of the Sec of State as well as to the system now established through the Colonies ... and I have to authorize ... the necessary measures for the disallowing of them accordingly /R 21 [Stanley to Elgin 11 May 1843] /v Bolland L 60 /// 30 Jul 1855 Belize T. Sup reports first sale of Crown Land since introduction of fees /R 48 [Stevenson to Barkly 30 Jul 1855] / 6 Mar 1868 Belize T. Lt Gov reports amt of Crown Lands sold = "utterly insignificant" /R 98 [Longden to Grant 6 Mar 1868] /v Bolland F 120"

NAME: Masters & Servants Ord
DESC: Public Meeting pass regulations to govern contracts between masters and servants, inc abolition of Sunday markets, possibly first formal labour code in Hon
CF: CO 123/50 [Minutes 6 Nov 1837 / Walker Report 12 Feb 1838] / CO 123/52 [Macdonald to Glenelg 29 Mar 1838] / CO 123/53 [Macdonald to Glenelg 28 Aug 1838] / Laws 1857 xxx
NOTE: 6 Nov 1837 Belize T. Pub Mtg appoint committee, on Sup recommendaiton, to consider proposals for "regulating the relative duties of Master and Servant" /CO 123/50 [Minutes 6 Nov 1837] /v Bolland F 115 /// 12 Feb 1838 Belize T. [Clerk of Cts to Sup] The employment of Household and all other servants, whether Journeymen or otherwise, within the Town of Belize, is regulated upon much the same principle as in England. The great bulk of the Lower Classes, however, and almost all the Charibs and Spaniards who resort to the Settlement, are employed in the Mah Works in the Interior, and with them it is the practice to enter into Contract by which they hire themselves generally for six or twelve months. This is usually done at the commencement or middle of the year, when the servant goes before a Mag, & volunteers a Contract for his services. It is the enforcement of these Contracts, however, that the great evil lies. There is no law on the subject further than what custom has sanctioned. That custom has been, that where the Servant has failed in his Contract, the Master has had the power to bring him up at once on Warrant, and have him summarily punished by Imprisonment and public Whipping. If however the breach of Contract lay with the Master,—If for example, the Master was deficient in the payments he had contract to make his servant, the Servant could only sue the Master as in the matter of a common debt. To send the Servant into Court for hte recovery of his wages amounts to an absolute denial of justice to him. People in his condition are not supposed to possess the means of their remaining for months at Belize to prosecute thier suits for those very earnings which would enable them to reside there for alittle. They only add to their embarrassment by being debarred from leaving the Town and entering into another contract. /CO 123/52 [Walker to Macdonald 12 Feb 1838] /v Bolland F 115–116 /// 29 Mar 1838 Belize T. Pub Mtg propose masters and servants ordinance which Sup considers "in a shape which I could not approve, for it was stripped of its most valuable provision ... for the recovery of Servants Wages and petty debts" /v Bolland F 116 /CO 123/52 [Macdonald to Glenelg 29 Mar 1838] /// 9 Jul 1838 Belize T. Pub Mtg resolutions re masters and servants inc redress by court for employers and employees, contracts in writing, and further abolishment of all Sunday markets /v Bolland F 116 /CO 123/53 [Macdonald to Glenelg 28 Aug 1838] /// 16 Jul 1838 Belize T. Pub Mtg, on HM Govt prompt, 'Resolved that all Sunday Markets in this Settlement be from henceforth totally abolished /Laws 1857 [16 Jul 1838] /v Bolland L 64 /// 1846–1852 Belize T. Labour code tightened in 1846 and in 1852, eg imposing 3 months imprisonment with hard labour on servant's breach of contract after receiving pre-season Christmas advance, allowing master to apprehend servant without warrant /R 20 [Minutes 20 Jan – 7 Feb 1852] /Laws 1857 [18 Vic ch 12] /v Bolland F 122"

NAME: Agricultural Co
DESC: Agricultural Co or Society established, possibly first such in Hon
CF: Hon Alm 1839 xxx / R 16 [Macdonald to Chairman 4 Mar 1839] / R 15 [Normanby to Macdonald 29 Jun 1839]
NOTE: 15 Nov 1833 Belize T. Pub Mtg ask grants of Crown land be authorised "for the general purposes of cultivation," which HM Govt deny on grounds that "the present is not a fitting opportunity for discussing with the Court of Spain the various questions which might arise" /R 6 [Cockburn to Sec 15 Nov 1833] /R 9 [Stanley to Cockburn 15 Apr 1834] /v Bolland L 51 /// 13 Feb 1835 Belize T. [Keeper of Records re labour for proposed cultivation of soil in Hon] emphasises "if it were intended to encourage a rapid and extensive scheme of Agriculture in Honduras ... it would be necessary to provide labour on a great scale" /CO 123/47 [Miller to Gladstone 13 Feb 1835] /v Bolland F 142 /// 9 Feb 1839 Belize T. fm the exhaustion of Mah the hitherto staple commodity, the permanent welfare of this place must mainly depend upon the rearing of colonial produce /R 14 [Macdonald to Sec 9 Feb 1839] /v Bolland F 139 /// 29 Jun 1839 Lon. Sec authorises grants of land for cultivation, though cannot admit Hon produce to English ports on same duty as that of other colonies /v Bolland F 136 /R 15 [Normanby to Macdonald 29 Jun 1839] /// 2 Mar 1841 Belize T. Inhabitants note petitions of 1833, 1835, 1839, further "The Cutting of [Mah and Log] having become a precarious Employment, your Petitioners are desirous of acquiring the unquestionable right of cultivating this extensive soil, witha bona fide Title of Propriety [Property?] in the Arable Lands thereof; and with unrestricted permission to export such cultivated products from this and to have them Imported into the United Kingdom, at the same rate of Duties as from the British West India Islands," though no reply to petition has been found /R 20 [Petition to HC 2 Mar 1841] /v Bolland F 136–137 /v Bolland L 67 /// 30 Jul 1855 Belize T. By all that I [Keeper of Records] can gather it would appear that the settlers indeed never considered that there was any impediment in the way of their cultivation of the soil, or turning their lands to any purpose, save that any produce they might export to GB would not be admitted under the same conditions as that of the recognized and favoured British Colonies, but would, on account of this settlement not being regarded as a colony or plantation, be charged with the duties imposed on articles the produce of Foreign Countries. Indeed, more than once the settlers attempted, but without success, to obtain from the Government a declaration of the extension of the Colonial Tariff to articles that produce of this Settlement. /R 54 [Farquharson to Stevenson 30 Jul 1855] /v Bolland L 51

NAME: Sp Hon re Mos Shore Mah concessions
DESC: Spanish Honduras use military force to dislodge or imprison workers, and seize property, of mahogany works in Mos Shore of some or several Honduras firms
PLACE: Río Bonito, Salt Creek, Sangrelaya, Piedra Blanca, Limas, Sereboyer [Ciriboya]
NON—SP 0: Antonio Mathe, John Carmichael, James Donald, Edward Usher, Oscar Rhys, William Cortnay, Robert Humel, George Pithketly
NON—SP 1: Frederick Chatfield, Charles Wycke, James Walker, Capt Granville Lock, Capt Watson, John Dixon, William Christie, James Green, HMS Sun, HMS Alarm, HMS Plumper
CF: FO 15/55 ff 91–98 / FO 15/49 [Carmichael to Addington 17 Apr 1847 / Usher to MacDonald 17 Jan 1847] / FO 53/5 [For Off to Walker 31 Dec 1847] / FO 53/7 f 10 [Mathe to Walker 20 Nov 1846 / Donald to Usher 28 Jan 1847 / McDonald to Walker 30 Jan 1847 / Walker to Loustalet 30 Apr 1847] / FO 53/8 [Mathe to Mos Cl 28 Apr 1847]
NOTE: See Sp Hon map in Revels 197 /// Fall 1845 Sp Hon send armed troops to imprison loggers and seize property of 2 Mathe & Co works in Mos Shore / Oct 1846 Río Bonito [Sp Hon]. Sp Hon [state or militia] demand payment for trees felled within Mos King grant to Mathe & Co / Early 1847 Sp Hon send troops to imprison loggers and seize property of 3 Mathe & Co works in Mos Shore / Spring 1847 Lon. Lord Palmerston undertakes full review of Mos–Sp Hon boundary / 1848 Belize T. Mathe & Co claim $103,938 in damages, though later on Chatfield [HM Min to CA] only submits a $16,344 claim to Sp Hon Govt / Aug 1847 Aguán R. Sp Hon demand payment for mahogany felled east of Aguan R [Mos Shore], to which Mathe & Co submit under protest / Aug 1848 Sp Hon detain loggers in 3 Mathe & Co works in Mos Shore, and demand $7,945 payment for felled mahogany, which is met / 10 Nov 1851 Col Mariano Alvarez 60 men dislodge loggers fm and seize company property [= £20,000 loss] in Limas and Río Aguán [Mos Shore] Mah works of Mathe & Co /v Revels 141–xxx /// 1 Jan 1848 Greytown. Fuerza bélica británica mosquita ocupó el poblado de San Juan del Norte, al que rebautizó con el nobre de Greytown /v Lujan 4 142

NAME: Hyde & Co est
DESC: James Hyde & Co established, possibly first Belize–Lon mercantile partnership in Hon
NON—SP 0: James Hyde, John Hodge, James Bartlett Hyde
NOTE: Though see 29 Jul 1848 Belize T. John Hodge notes his interests in Belize T had existed "for more than twenty years" /v Bolland 183 /R 20 [Minutes 29 Jul 1848]

NAME: Lee wreck
DESC: Packet schooner Lee wrecked, possibly due to negligence by lighthouse keeper
NOTE: [Jan 1849 Lon] WRECKS OF BRITISH SHIPPING. The Lee, of --, master Greaves, fm Havana, to Belize, wrecked at Gloucester [?], on June 10 [1848] /Naut Mag 1849 160 Link: https://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066363916?urlappend=%3Bseq=186%3Bownerid=13510798882112395-184 /// Gulf of Mexico, December, 15th 1848. The charges upon the shipping are enormous in Honduras, and what do they receive in return? ... At Belize you pay half a dollar per ton, called "tonnage dues", and thirty dollars clearance; eight dollars harbour master, and one dollar for each man and boy on board as hospital dues; and for all this in its intricate channels there is neither *buoy* nor *beacon*. There is a small light at Mauger Cay, but *no dependance* can be placed on it being lighted or kept burning; another small light at English Cay, which I observed was not lighted until an *hour after* sun-set; the "sun-set to sun-rise" rule is more particularly required here, where there is little or no twilight; but repeated instances occurred of the important light upon Half Moon Cay, not being *lighted* or allowed to *go out*; and it has since come out that there was *no light burning* there when the *Packet Schooner "Lee" was wrecked*. The new light is good provided that it be attended to. The cause of neglect which has occurred with the old light, should not be heard of in a country making any pretentions to *civilization*, much less where the British flag flies. I am, &c, R. LEIGHTON, Master of the barque Royal Adelaide. /Naut Mag 1849 242 Link: https://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066363916?urlappend=%3Bseq=268%3Bownerid=13510798882112395-266

NOTE: See Martha Herminia Villalobos González, *El bosque sitiado: asaltos armados, concesiones forestales y estrategias de resistencia durante la Guerra de Castas* [Mexico, CIESAS, 2006], 115–116 / O.
