NAME: Wodehouse appt Gov
DESC: Sir Philip Endmond Wodehouse appointed Superintendent, likely first one not from a military background
NOTE: Fm Hon. We have Hon Watchman to 14th [Jun 1851]. ... Mr. Wodenside, the new Sup in place of Col Fancourt, had arrived. It is thought that he will be popular with the people, as he seems to be a working man. It will require an excellent administration of affairs, however, to restore the settlement to its former prosperity, as some have already become disgusted with the existing state of affairs. One or two merchants have already left Belize [T] on this account. We learn that most of the mahogany in Belize is exhausted, and that the cutting establishments are going into Mos country and Sp Honduras to procure supplies. ... /Times-Picayune sn 2 = 24 June 1851 [Evening Ed]

NAME: Catholic parish est
DESC: Fr Eustace du Peyron, a Jesuit fm Jam, establishes first Roman Catholic parish in Hon
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Joint Stock Companies Act
DESC: Eng Parliament pass Joint Stock Companies Act 1856
NOTE: 1846 Lon. Corn Laws, Sugar Duties Act abolished / 1848 Navigation Laws repealed / 1859 Lon. John Hodge, James Bartlett Hyde [formerly of James Hyde & Co] register as Ltd Co under name BH Co Ltd, fm 1875 onwards known as Belize Estate & Produce Co Ltd /R 70 [Young to Rogers 2 Aug 1860] / 1881 Belize T. Bel Est & Prod Co buys nine Young Toledo & Co mahogany works upon the latter's bankruptcy in 1880 /v Bolland F 184, 186 /v Bolland L 80 /// 1947 Bel Est & Prod Co sold to J. Glicksten & Sons Ltd, which thereafter merged with other companies to form Intl Timber Corp, based in UK /v Bolland L 107

NAME: Walker capture
DESC: Hon or Mos Shore capture William Walker and American filibusters, and turn them over to Sp Hon
NOTE: 17 Sep 1860 Guat. La captura de Walker y su gente se verificó en la entrada del Rio Tinto, costa mosquita hondurena. Rendidos â discreción á las autoridades de [Sp] Honduras, W'alker y sus gentes fueron embarcados en el vapor de guerra "Icarus" y conducidos á Truxillo. La autoridad del puerto dispuso pasar por lar armas el dia 7 á Walker y su segundo el titulado Coronel Rudgeley. Toda la demas gente iba á ser despachada para Nueva Orleans, despues de haber prestado juramento de no volver á tomar armas contra Centro-America. Estas noticias fueron comunicadas en Belice por el "Icarus," que llegó á aquel puerto, procedente de Truxillo, el 10 del corriente. Como se habia previsto, el gefe de los aventureros ha pagado con la vida los males que ha causado á Centro-América, poniendo término el patíbulo á su temeraria aventura. /Huntington B call no 384943 [Últimas noticias a 17 sep 1860] Link: https://catalog.huntington.org/record=b1404652 /// [> 30 Sep 1860 Lon?] [Rodmond addressing Nautical Club] *filibustering* in the West Indies would perhaps cease for awhile since the great filibustier, General Walker, had paid the penalty of his piratical proceedings ... That misguided individual, the Freebooter General Walker, had at length run into the lion's mouth and found the fate he had so richly deserved. The last record of him may be worth preserving in our annals. A reward of two thousand dollars had been offered for his capture. H.M.S. *Icarus*, Commander N. Salmon, with a transport of troops under the command of Alvarez, had proceeded to Rio Negro, where Walker and his band had encamped. The boats of the *Icarus* passed up the river, captured Walker and seventy of his men, all of whom had been taken back to Truxillo, and given up to the authorities of [Sp] Honduras. Many of the men being sick, were permitted to return to the United States, on condition of never again engaging in an expedition against Central America. As for Walker and one of his colonerls, named Kudler, they were to be shot. And thus the freebooter met his fate. Being condemned, but with difficulty saved from popular fury, in his six days of imprisonment he had ample time for thought, and conscience smote him on contemplating his prison, and also on seeing the people that he had defeated and driven from their homes on the 6th of August [1860?] treating him with the greatest benevolence and kindness. Carried to the place of death and being ready to be executed, he begged leave to address the people in these few words:—"I declare myself to be a member of the Roman Catholic church. I declare that I have injured the people of [Sp] Honduras to a great extent, being led to do so by the people of the island of Ruatan, who, after calling me, deceived me and left me to my fate. I ask pardon for the poor men that accompanied me, for they are not so guilty as I am. If my life can be of any benefit to society I lay it down with the greatest readiness, pardoning my judges, that I may be enabled to obtain my pardon in the next world." These were his last words, and with these the scene closed; it being worthy of notice that although the port of Truxillo was attacked ruthlessly by him, yet the people of the town pitied him, and in the whole crown there was not one glad countenance. /Naut Mag 1860 605–606 Link: https://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066364856?urlappend=%3Bseq=613%3Bownerid=13510798882112364-669 /// See Regis A. Courtemanche, *The Historian* 30(3), "The Royal Navy and the End of William Walker" [1968], 350–365 Link: https://www.jstor.org/stable/24441212

NAME: Census expanded
DESC: First census to account for categories other than White, Coloured, Black, Slaves [or Apprenticed Labourers]
NOTE: 1871, 1881, 1891, 1911, 1921, 1931 Censuses do not include racial or ethnic categories /v Cunin 40 /// Though categories retained in other Govt docs eg Hon Hnd 1888-89 [= Native, Ladino or Spaniard or Spanish, Coloured or Creole, Carib] /v Cunin 42

NAME: Unratified Anglo–Guat Convention
DESC: Anglo–Guatn Convention re Wyke–Aycinena Treaty signed, but ratified by neither party
NOTE: 11 Nov 1865 Guat. Guat belatedly ratifies Wyke–Martin Convention, though UK Sec Clarendon points out the ratification is too belated, such that UK Parl would not vote for it / 30 Jul 1866 Lon. Sec Stanley informs Guat Consul, Francisco Martín, that HM Govt cannot ratify the Wyke–Martín Convention, as the deadline for ratification has expired /v Lujan 4 226 /// 3 Jan 1867 Lon. Lord Stanley informs Guat Consul, Francisco Martín, that HM Govt "declina firmar de nuevo la Convención de 1863 y se considera, por ahora, exonerado de la obligación contraída por el Art. 7º de la de 1859" / 15 Nov 1867 Lon. Sec Clarendon reaffirms HM Govt position to Guat Consul /v Lujan 4 227–229 /// 30 Jun 1880 Lon. Guat Consul, Crisanto Medina, informs Sec Granville Guat demands UK fulfill article 7 of the Convention of 1859, calls for arbitration / 18 Aug 1880 Lon. Sec Granville informs Guat Consul HM Govt position re 1859 Convention has not changed, and does not believe there is any reason for arbitration / 5 Apr 1884 Lon. Guat protests “contra la creciente ocupación de hecho, por parte de la Gran Bretaña, de una parte integral del territorio guatemalteco, declarando que mientras no exista un acuerdo perfecto sobre este punto entre los dos países, dicha ocupación no puede perjudicar los derechos de Guat en ningún tiempo,” though HM Govt only notes receipt of said protest / 1882 Washington. US Sec, Frederick T. Frelinghuysen, se refirió al dominio indebido que GB ejercía en Belice y al incumplimiento del Tratado de 1859 [Wyke–Aycinena] /v Lujan 4 230

NAME: Leg Assy re Belize T
DESC: Legislative Assembly transfer governance of Belize Town to a District Board
NOTE: 1856 Sup recommends est of Town Bd /v Schoburgh 197 /xxx /// Possibly see 1849 Belize T. Northern Dist created, Mag named for it / 1856 Belize T. District Mags entitled Commissioners /v Ribot 119–196

NAME: Indian Proclamation
DESC: Proclamation placing restrictions on Mayan settlers
NOTE: 6 Mar 1868 Belize T. [Re Mayan villages in W Dist] Several of these villages are situate upon lands claimed either by the BH Co or Messrs Young Toledo & Co, but whenever they are situate on Crown Lands I think the villages and a sufficient surrounding space should be reserved in the hands of the Crown for the use of the Indians,—no marketable titles being issued to them to enable them to dispose of such lands. /R 98 [Longden to Grant 6 Mar 1868] / 1872 Belize T. Crown Lands Ordinance of 1872 creates reservations for Mayans, precluding private ownership /v Bolland F 131

NAME: Pub Mtg encourage immigration
DESC: Act passed to encourage importation of labourers
NOTE: 27 May 1868 Belize T. By this act any person may import into this colony labourers fm any place whatsoever ... [and] shall receive fm the Immigration Funds a bounty of one third of the passage money of such labourers, not exceeding, however, in any case £5 for a man or women, or £3–6–8 for each child ... If a few hundred negroes accustomed to the actual cultivation of the sugar-cane, can be brought fm America or fm any of our own colonies, where there is an excess in the supply of labour over the demand, I have reason to believe that sure and rapid progress would be made in agriculture. There appears to be no lack of capital here ... but the great want of all the landowners is a supply of labourers accustomed to the cultivation of the sugar cane. /R 98 /Bolland F 143–144

NAME: Mag Ct re strike
DESC: Lucas Howel and 30 others leave work at Regalia Estate without leave or lawful excuse, upon which Magistrate orders their pay docked
NOTE: Possibly first non-slavery strike in Hon? /// 17 Feb 1870 Belize T. [Mag reports] The defendants were put by the Manager of Regalia Estate to cut canes by day work, which they did not like, wishing to work by task, but which the Manager would not consent to, as they hurried through their work and did not cut the canes properly. The defendants then left off working at 10 o'c in the morning and came down to Allpines to ask me to compel the Manager to give them task work ... I think their principal reason for striking was to try and frighten the Manager into what they wanted. This happened during crop and the Mill had to be stopped for the day. They were by my advice arrested and tried and I ordered each of them to pay their employers the sum of $2.50 and the costs of $1.50 which they consented to do, and the Manager agreed to stop it out of their wages. /R 106 /v Bolland F 154

NAME: Guat invasion of Sp Hon
DESC: Guat invades Sp Hon, after which Hon and Jam provide Sp Hon Govt-in-Exile with military help and volunteers to retake Sp Hon
SP: Miguel García Granados, Gen José María Medina
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Crown Lands Ord
DESC: Leg Co pass Crown Lands Ordinance, est reserves for Mayan and Garifuna settlements or barring freehold land titles by them
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Anniversary of Abolition
DESC: Fiftieth anniversary of abolition is celebrated, possibly first such in Hon
PRESS: Colonial Guardian [Belize] xxx = 21 Jul 1888 / Colonial Guardian [Belize] xxx = 4 Aug 1888
NOTE: Repeated 1 Aug 1889, when lot granted for People's Hall by Gov, subsequently destroyed in Jul 1893 by severe tropical storm /v Appelbaum 116

NAME: Turkish arrivals
DESC: Turks [= Palestinians, Lebanese, Syrians] settle in Hon
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Hunter contract affair
DESC: British court finds Hon responsible for cancelled contract of English engineer C. T. Hunter, and Leg Co comply, upon which five unofficials resign in protest, whereupon Gov forms unconstitutional all-official Leg Co
NON—SP 0: Gov Roger Goldsworthy, C. T. Hunter, Henry Fowler, Gov George Melville
PRESS: Colonial Guardian [Belize] xxx = 8 Mar 1890 / Colonial Guardian [Belize] xxx = 19 Apr 1890
NOTE: 1880 Belize T. Col Off send Baron Siccamam, Dutch engineer, to see how best to part with Treasury surplus in improvement of sanitation of the capital eg cleaning of canals and dredging of harbour /v Ashdown 53 /// 6 Mar 1890 Belize T. Public meeting petition Col Off protest Lon arbitraion by John Gentle and Sir Benjamin Pine /v Ashdown 56 /// 16 Apr 1890 Belize T. Gov uses casting vote in Leg Co to accede to Lon arbitration in favour of C. T. Hunter, whereupon five unofficial members walk out /v Ashdown 57 /// 22 Apr 1890 Belize T. Unofficials' walk out endorsed by public meeting, petition Col Off again, appoint a People’s Committee to consider constitutional reform /v Ashdown 57 /// Jan 1891 Belize T. Gov George Melville fills four vacant seats in Leg Co with official members ie civil servants, whereupon People's Committee charge Leg Co as unconsitutional /v Ashdown 62 /// See H. Siccama, *Report on the drainage and improvements proposed for the town and harbour of Belize, British Honduras* [Belize, Government Press, 1880] OCLC = http://gw.worldcat.org.proxygw.wrlc.org/oclc/1204388737

NAME: Rerum novarum
DESC: Rerum novarum published
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Melinda tramway opened
DESC: The Melinda tramway of four miles in Stann Creek valley is completed, possibly first man-made line of communication in Hon
NOTE: < 1892 A few miles of road completed around Corozal T /v Ashdown 95

NAME: Beresford nurse training est
DESC: Nurse Marian Edith Beresford establishes a nurse training programme at the Public Hospital, possibly first instance
NOTE: 1820s Matron Louis Robert expands the programme / 1926 Act of Parliament reforms programme as a Nursing School / 1963 Nursing School reformed as Bliss School of Nursing /v Aird xxx

NAME: Mestizo MP
DESC: Jose Maria Rosado appointed member of Leg Co or Ex Co, possibly first mestizo
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Payo Obispo est
DESC: Payo Obispo [= present-day Chetumal City] establihed
NOTE: 22 Jan 1898 Vc-Adm Blanco arrives at northern bank of Hondo R mouth ie Payo Obispo in Pontón Chetumal / See See Rafael I. Romero Mayo & Jazmín Benítez López, *Península* 9(1), "El proceso histórico de conformación de la antigua Payo Obispo (Hoy Chetumal) como espacio urbano fronterizo durante la etapa de Quintana Roo como territorio federal" [2014] Link: http://www.scielo.org.mx/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S1870-57662014000100006

NAME: Labour Assn est
DESC: Reginald Uter founds a Labour Association, possibly first formal labour group in Hon
NOTE: 20 May 1899 Belize T. Labour Assn lead protest of unemployed men against curt dismissal by Gov Wilson of Labour Assn grievances re distress over reduced wages for 1899 logging season /v Ashdown 88 /// 17 Jul 1900 Belize T. Labour Assn meets Gov asking relief from increased import duties, which Gov refuses, whereupon mob nearly turns violent, forcing police intervention /v Ashdown 89 /// 25 Aug 1900 Belize T. Gov Wilson denounces Reginald Uter as 'a worthless negro carpenter who has never remained at work any length of time in one place [but who has] made it his business to do a great deal of talking amongst his race' /v Ashdown G 42–43 /Colonial Guardian [Belize] xxx = 25 Aug 1900

NAME: Colonial Loan Act
DESC: Eng Parl pass Colonial Loan Act of 1899, possibly first non-ad hoc programme of aid to colonies
NOTE: See George C. Abbott, *Economic History Review* 24(1), "A Re-Examination of the 1929 Colonial Development Act" [1971]

NAME: Gov, Leg Cl re United Fruit Co
DESC: United Fruit Company threaten suspension of mail service to Hon unless granted a $14,500 subsidy, which the Legislative Council oppose, upon which Governor Wilson suspends rules of order of Leg Cl to pass a $12,000 subsidy
PRESS: Colonial Guardian [Belize] xxx 3 = 8 Mar 1902 / Colonial Guardian [Belize] xxx 3 = 26 Jul 1902
CF: CO 123/240 [Wilson to Col Off 13 Feb 1902 / Fairweather, Cuthbert, Woods to Col Off 6 Mar 1902]
NOTE: 1900 United Fruit Co acquires Belize Royal Mail & Central American Steamship Co, holder of Hon subsidised mail contract /v Moberg 366

NAME: De Mendez eviction affair
DESC: Senora de Mendez, landlord in San Pedro [Ambergris], evicts tenants without customary compensation, whereupon Leg Co pass Ordinance 17 of 1908 requiring compensation on eviction of tenants after tenancy of three generations or more, as per custom
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Belize T Board protest
DESC: All members of the Belize District Board resign in protest over row regarding purchase of new fire engines
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Masica incident
DESC: West Indian citizens Alexander Thurston, Wilfred Robinson, Joseph Holland assaulted by Sp Hon soldiers, fatally in case of Thurston
NON—SP 0: Alexander Thurston, Wilfred Robinson, Joseph Holland
NOTE: See *Arrangement between the United Kingdon and Honduras referring to arbitration matters relating to the Masica insident* [Lon, HMSO, 1914] OCLC = http://gw.worldcat.org.proxygw.wrlc.org/oclc/48208232 / *Incidente de La Masica* [Tegucigalpa, sn, 1914] OCLC = http://gw.worldcat.org.proxygw.wrlc.org/oclc/499922861

NAME: Suffrage re-introduced
DESC: Leg Co pass Ordinance 18 of 1911, re-introducing limited or partial suffrage for local government of Belize T in form of elected Town Board
NOTE: 30 Sep 1911 Belize T. Nine members elected by proportional representation to newly constituted Belize Town Board /v Ashdown 122 /// Nov 1918 Belize T. Progressive Party est /v Ashdown 169

NAME: Women’s suffrage
DESC: Propertied women receive suffrage
NOTE: Possibly see, Linnette Vassell, *Jamaican Historical Review* 15(11), "The Movement for the Vote for Women 1918–1919" [1993], 40–54

NAME: Brito affair
DESC: Mexican Governor of Campeachy Manuel Brito illicitly smuggles arms via Belize T with aid of Perdomo Bros Co
NON—SP 0: Carlos Melhado, Habet Perdomo, Sabela Perdomo
CF: CO 123/276 [No 28538] / CO 123/277 [No 44465] / R 128 [Collet to Harcourt 5 Feb 1914]
NOTE: xnp

NAME: UNIA est
DESC: Marcus Garvey establishes the Universal Negro Improvement Association and African Communities League
NOTE: 1910 Belize T. Marcus Garvey visits Hon during 1910–1911 CA Tour /v Ashdown G 50 fn 60 /Clarion [Belize] xxx = 7 Jul 1921 /// 1914 Belize T. Hubert Hill Cain est Belize Independent, a Garveyite paper /v Goldthree 80–81 /// 1914–1919 Belize T. Marked deterioration in race relations caused by growth of black consciousness fostered by radical Herbert Hill Cain via Belize Independent paper, which emphasised black achievement, many examples of black humiliation, and ran column called 'The Garvey Eye' by columnist L. D. Kemp / See L. D. Kemp, *Upward Climb* [Belize, sn, 1962?], 2 /v Ashdown G 44–45 /// 1918 Hon. UNIA Negro World paper circulating in lg numbers in Hon /v Ashdown G 45 /CO 123/296 [Allen memo] /// Jan 1919 Belize T. UNIA Negro World paper banned by Acting-Gov Robert Walter, though continues to be smuggled in via Guat and Mex /v Ashdown 152 /v Ashdown G 45 /CO 123/295 [Hutson to Milner 30 Jul 1919 / Hutson to Milner 31 Jul 1919] /FO 371/4567 [Hutson to Milner 10 May 1920] /// Feb 1919 Belize T. Act Gov Walter receives deputation led by Cain asking Negro World circulate freely, but rejects the petition /v Ashdown G 45 /CO 123/295 [Hutson to Milner 31 Jul 1919] /// 7 Nov 1919 Marcus Garvey posts 50 copies of Negro World paper to D. B. Lewis in Corozal T, promises to send 50 per week in future /v Goldthree 242 /NARA Record Group 165 10218-261/2 [USPS Censorship Report 7 Nov 1919] / See W. F. Elkins, *Science & Society* 35(3), "Suppression of the Negro World in the British West Indies" [1971] /v Goldthree 245 fn 42 /// 10 May 1920 Belize T. Gov Hutson opines Negro World should be unbanned /v Ashdown G 45–46 /FO 371/4567 [Hutson to Milner 10 May 1920] /// < 22 Apr 1920 Belize T. Local branch of UNIA founded under Gen Sec Samuel Haynes /v Ashdown 155 /v Ashdown G 46 /Clarion [Belize] xxx = 29 Apr 1920 /// 1 Jul 1921 Marcus Garvey visits Hon / 5 Jul 1921 Belize T. Marcus Garvey meets Gov at Govt House /v Straughan 104 /v Ashdown 156 /v Ashdown G 47–49 /Clarion [Belize] xxx = 7 Jul 1921 /FO 371/5684 [Hutson to Churchill 14 Jul 1921 Enc 1–5] /// [1934?] Belize T. Matron Vivian Seay, w Govt patronage, est local branch of the Black Cross Nurses /v Ashdown G 49 /Belize Independent xxx = 22 Jan 1934 / See R. E. Hadel, *National Studies* 2(1), "Builders of Belize (3) Nurse Seay" [1977], 8–11 /v Ashdown G 49 /// Feb 1941 Belize T. Lionel Francis, President of UNIA Inc of NYC, takes residence in Hon /v Ashdown G 52 /Belize Independent xxx = 19 Feb 1941 /Belize Independent xxx = 26 Feb 1941

NAME: Volstead Act
DESC: US Congress enacts Volstead Act to effect alcohol prohibition, whereupon Hon merchants illicitly smuggle alcohol to US
NOTE: 1921–1932 Hon merchants illicitly re-export 902,772 gallons of whisky = $4,350,266 to US, with main smugglers being Melhado & Melhado /v Ashdown 190 /Cmd. 4586 209  /// 15 Dec 1927 Belize T Burdon to Amery. Informs is loathe to stem tide of illicit whisky to US as 'it would involve a sacrifice which I am extremely reluctant to impose on a penurious and struggling Colony' /v Ashdown 190 /R 144 [Burdon to Amery 15 Dec 1927]

NAME: Hon Soc est
DESC: Honduran Society of New York established by Hon expatriates, possibly first not in WI or UK, or first by former Hon residents
NOTE: 1930s NY. Hon Soc host Antonio Soberanis /v Straughan 160 fn 49 /Donohoe 56

NAME: Mexico racially restricts entry
DESC: Immigration officer at Payo Obispo [= present-day Chetumal, Q. Roo, Mex] denies entry fm Hon to David Humes, on grounds of his belonging to the "black race"
NOTE: Dec 1925 Immigration Dept of Mex rules "it was absolutely opposed to letting in individuals of inferior races [= Ethiopian and Mongol races]" /v Cunin B 346 /// 12 Jun 1929 Payo Obispo. Professor of tropical agriculture, Miguel Augusto Memhart, fm Hon, denied entry to Mex "because he belongs to the black race and does not fulfil the requirements of the immigration law" / c Jul 1929 Secretaría de Governación of Mex orders Payo Obispo immigration officer to allow Prof Memhart entry /v Cunin B 345 /// 2 Jan 1926 Payo Obispo immigration office. Deems Creole or Garifuna [forestry] workers indispensable for the [Mex] Federation's interest, reports support of Gov of Q. Roo, high-ranking military on this; requests excepional treatment for Q. Roo; notes "Shoud the immigration of blacks be banned, forestry would have to be stopped because nobody would be able to replace them” / 1 Mar 1926 Mex Immigration Dept authorises requested exemption for Q. Roo /v Cunin B 347

NAME: Morter estate suits
DESC: Vars lawsuits in Sup Ct and Privy Council re estate of Isaiah Morter of c $300,000 bequeathed to the 'parent body of the UNIA for the African Redemption Fund’
NOTE: Mar 1926 Belize T. CJ rules UNIA exists for an 'illegal purpose' (the redemption of Africa by violent means), such that Morter's will is invalid and estate devolves on dependants, which judgement overturned in Feb 1928 by Privy Council /R 150 [Amery to Burdon 20 Mar 1938] / Feb 1931 CJ determines 'parent body' named in Morter will = UNIA Inc of NYC, which judgement subsequently endorsed on 30 Jul 1935 by Privy Council /v Ashdown G 50 / See A. J. Garvey, *Garvey and Garveyism* [New York, sn, 1970], 260–261 /v Ashdown G 50

NAME: HM Govt, Gov powers expanded
DESC: Legislative Council pass BH Constitutional (Amendment) Ordinance No 17 of 1932, granting reserve powers over public funds and legislation to Gov and HM Treasury, as required by HM Govt for disbursement of Hurricane Reconstruction Loan
NOTE: 1932–1936 Hon = pure Crown Colony /v Ashdown D 72 no 10

NAME: Western border demarcated
DESC: Western border with Guat unilaterally demarcated by Hon
NOTE: 5 Feb 1933 Lon. HM Govt ask Guat to appt engineers to demarcate western border w Hon, upon which Guat demands fulfilment of article 7 of 1859 Convention /v Lujan 5 113 /Guat 1938 1 349–350, 354

NAME: Suffrage expanded
DESC: Legislative Council pass Ordinance to Provide for the Constitution and Legislative Council of the Colony No 13 of 1935, granting limited or partial suffrage for election of members to the Leg Co
NOTE: 17 Nov 1921 Belize T. Sydney Cuthbert, senior unofficial member of Leg Co, and Frans Dragten, of BH Electoral Reform Assn, petition return of elective principle to Leg Co / Jan 1923 Lon. Col Off inform Gov of no objection to re-introduction of elective principle to Leg Co, advise set up commission for implementation /v Ashdown 169–170 /// Jun 1924 Belize T. Commission's report and draft bills tabled before Leg Co, whereupon unofficial members demand Gov have no reserve power over public funds /v Ashdown 172 /// Mar–Apr 1925 Belize T + District Capitals. Public meetings held to consider Commission's report and proposed constitutional bills inc reserve powers for Gov /v Ashdown 172–173 /// 6 Apr 1925 Belize T. Leg Co reject proposed constitutional bills, thereby opposing Gov, Col Off and public opinion /v Ashdown 173–175 /// Feb 1936 Hon. Elections held for five unofficial members of Leg Co [total of seven unofficial members in Leg Co] /v Ashdown 219 /// 1939 Belize T. One elected unofficial member of Leg Co added [total six elected and two appointed unofficials] /v Ashdown 246 / 1945 Belize T. Two appointed unofficial members added to Leg Co [total six elected four appointed unofficials], and official members reduced to three /v Ashdown 245–246

NAME: Garifuna arrivals
DESC: Garifuna refugees arrive in Stann Creek, fleeing persecution by Sp Hon army
NOTE: Garifuna who once resided in [Sp] Hon tell of widespread atrocities committed by the army. Older residents [of Stann Creek] recount in graphic terms the arrival of dugout dories overloaded with refugees fm [Sp] Hon. Many refugees settle in Newtown and accompanied residents of that village to Hopkins in the 1940s. /v Moberg C 39

NAME: Belize T Board dissolved
DESC: Gov dissolves the Belize Town Board, being riddled with graft, and replaces it with a temporary nominated Board
NOTE: Jan 1939 Belize T. Elections held for elected Belize T Board /v Ashdown 220

NAME: Lahoodie–Adderly plot
DESC: Members of the Belize Independent Labour Party / People's Republican Party / People's National Committee plan a coup d'etat
NOTE: Early 1941 Corozal T. Adderly and Lahoodie detained for six months under defence regulations /v Ashdown 241

NAME: Atlantic Charter
DESC: xxx
NOTE: 1941 Lon. Col Off states some colonies might achieve dominion status in "far distant future", while other never would for strategic considerations inc Gibraltar, Malta, Cyprus and Aden, and for vars reasons Gambia, Borneo, Malaya, Hong Kong, Bermuda, Fiji, Falkland Isl, Brit Hon / See W. R. Louis, *Imperialism at Bay, 1941–1945: The United States and the Decolonisation of the British Empire* [Oxford, sn, 1977], 126 / R. Smith, *Journal of Imperial & Commonwealth History* 14(sn), "Britain's African Colonies and British Propaganda during the Second World War" [1985], 74, 76

NAME: Labour offences partly decriminalised
DESC: Legislative Council pass Employers and Workers Ordinance, making some but not all breaches of work contracts civil rather than criminal offences
NOTE: 1883 Masters and Servants Ordinance / 1918 Fraudulent Labourers Ordinance /v Ashdown 235

NAME: TWU registered
DESC: Tradesmen’s and Worker’s Union, established 1939, registers as a trade union with Govt, being first so recognised in Hon
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Brit Hon Scholarship est
DESC: Governor J. A. Hunter and the Legislative Council establish merit-based British Honduras Scholarship for university college tuition, possibly first Government Exhibition awards for tertiary schooling
NON—SP 0: Gov J. A. Hunter, C. M. Staine
NOTE: Jan 1935 Belize T Easter Report. J. B. Easter, Director of Education in Jam, recommends teacher training in Jam, possibly at The Mico University College / 1935 Lon. Easter Report recommends est of scheme of awards to UK universities / 1941 Belize T. Four [trainee] teachers leave for training to Jam / 1948 First Brit Hon Scholarship awarded / 22 Dec 1948 Mona [Jam]. University College of West Indies [inc Hon] established by Royal Charter of King George VI / 1952 St. John’s College est a sixth form to prepare students for A Levels for entry to UCWI / 1954 Belize T. Govt Teacher Training College est with inaugural intake of 15 students /v Aird 59–76

NAME: Truman Doctrine
DESC: xxx
NOTE: xnp

NAME: ’A Downright Shame’ published
DESC: ‘A Downright Shame’ pamphlet, by Lloyd Griffiths, published and clandestinely circulated, upon which distributors are arrested
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Garifuna MP
DESC: C. J. Benguche becomes member of Leg Co or Ex Co, possibly first Garifuna
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Mexico conditionally claims Hon
DESC: Mexico claims Hon or part of Hon in event of its transfer to Guat
NOTE: Possibly see < 1949 Mexico. Isidro Fabela publishes *Belice : Defensa de los derechos de México*, arguing that in case Hon passes to a republic in the Americas, Mexico would have to claim territory between Hondo and Sibun R / > 30 May 1949. Desde entonces, México obstaculizó en todas formas la reclamación de Guat. ... el gobierno mexicano se tornó campeón de la libre determinación del pueblo beliceño y patrocinó ante las Naciones Unidas varias resoluciones en favor de la independencia de Belice /v Lujan 6 171

NAME: PUP est
DESC: People’s United Party established
NOTE: 31 Dec 1949 Belize T. People’s Committee formed /xxx /// Possibly see [1950s] El Popular Unión Party (P. U. P.) de Belice, jefeado por Mr. George Price, después de algunas negociaciones, años antes, resolvió tomar partido por Guat. Esta adquisición se debe íntegra al Señor Licenciado Jorge García Granados (padre). Mi Gobierno le prestó toda clase de ayudas especialmente la pecuniaria y reforzó la organización de este partido opositor a los ingleses y que bien podríamos llamar la "Quinta Columna", que iba en crescendo a diario. Años después, una de tantas veces vino a vernos Mr. Price y nos reunimos con él en el Despacho Presidencial, el Ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, Lic. Jesús Unda Murillo y el ya mencionado Lic. García Granados (padre) y otros miembros del Comité Pro-Belice. Habló, más o menos así, Mr. Price: "Yo he tomado la causa de Guat, porque mi madre es guatemalteca. Mi padre y yo somos beliceños. Quiero a Guat, pero quiero más a Belice. Los ingleses ya se han enterado por su servicio de Inteliencia, de estas pláticas. Están rápidamente trabajando para contraarrestarlas. Les advierto a ustedes que si no se apuran a tomar una decisión definitiva, y los ingleses entretanto, me hacen una proposición definitiva, y los ingleses entretanto, me hacen una proposición tan buena o mejor que la de Guat, y más rápida para ponerla en práctica, yo los abandono a ustedes, y me paso con mi partido al lado de Inglaterra." ... Teníamos, pues, que movernos y ganar la carrera a los ingleses. /Idigoras 15–16 /// 24 Nov 1953 Lon. Sec Oliver Lyttelton informs UK Cabinet of rumours re Guat financing of PUP /v Lujan 6 43 /CAB 128 [Conclusion No 70 24 Nov 1953 / Conclusion No 9 17 Feb 1954]

NAME: Radio est
DESC: Radio programming = British Honduras Broadcasting introduced via UK funding and technical support
NOTE: xnp

NAME: US McCarran–Walter Act
DESC: Passage of Immigration and Nationality Act 1952 in US Congress
NOTE: Introduces discriminatory quotas applicable to entries fm WI inc Hon / Re similar provisions in CA see Elisavinda Echeverri-Gent, *Journal of Latin American Studies* 24(sn), "Forgotten Workers: British West Indians and the Early Days of the Banana Industry in Costa Rica and Honduras" [1992] /v Straughan 142–143

NAME: Suffrage expanded
DESC: Legislative Council pass BH Constitution Ordinance No 13 of 1954, granting universal adult suffrage
NOTE: Apr 1954 Hon. Elections for re-constituted Leg Co or Leg Assy / Oct 1954 Lon. PUP leaders meet with HM Govt / 1 Jan 1955 Belize T. Three unofficials in Leg Assy appointed to Ex Co for natural resources, public utilities and social services /v Swan 33–34 /// Possibly see T. D. Vickers, *The Legislature of British Honduras* [Belize, sn, 1953], 26 /v Bolland F 207 no 31

NAME: Downie Report
DESC: Report on whether agriculture or forestry should by emphasised by Govt
NOTE: See Jack Downie, *An Economic Policy for British Honduras* [Belize, Govt Printer, 1959] /v Bolland L 139 no 19

NAME: Mennonite arrivals
DESC: Mennonite families fm Old Colony Church and Kleine Gemeinde, in Mexico, settle in Spanish Lookout
NON—SP 0: Peter H. W. Wiebe, Peter S. Madison
NOTE: Possibly see Alardo Prats, *Visión actual de Belice* [Mexico, Libro Mex, 1958] / Gerhard S. Koop, *Pioneer years in British Honduras (Belize)* [Belize, Country Graphics & Printing, 1991] / Harry Leonard Sawatzky, *They Sought a Country: Mennonite colonization in Mexico (with an appendix on Mennonite Colonization in British Honduras)* [Berkeley, U of California Press, 1971]

NAME: Ydigoras incursion
DESC: President of Guat, Gen Miguel Ydígoras Fuentes, makes unannounced visit to Benque Viejo and declares Hon Guatn territory
CF: Ydigoras 8–12 / AHD exp III-2260-19 [Cónsul a SRE 16 Apr 1958 / Memo presidencial]
NOTE: Possibly see 14 Jun 1958 Price visits Guat /v Hoshino 35 /AHD exp III-1924-2 [Cónsul a SRE 15 Jun 1958] / 11 Sep 1958 Price visits Guat /v Hoshino 36 /AHD exp III-1924-2 [Embajador a SRE 11 Sep 1958] / 13 Sep 1958 Guat Govt announce military mobilisation by UK in Hon-Guat border /v Hoshino 36 /AHD xxx [Cónsul a SRE 14 Sep 1958]

NAME: Unofficial majority in Ex Cl
DESC: Legislative Council pass BH Constitution (Amendment) Ordinance No 12 ofo 1960, granting elected [unofficial?] majority in Legislative Assembly and in the Executive Council
NOTE: xnp

NAME: UNGA Res 1514
DESC: UN Gen Assy pass Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples by 89-0, with 9 abstentions
NOTE: 7 Nov 1975 NYC. Hon PM George Cadle Price asks UNGA to apply Res 1514 to Hon, which Guat delegate Jorge Skinner Klée argues against /v Lujan 6 173

NAME: Gov powers restricted
DESC: xxx
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Webster proposals
DESC: US mediates Hon border or sovereignty question at prompting of Hon, UK and Guat
NOTE: 3–6 May 1965 Miami. UK–Guat conference re Hon / 25 May 1965 Lon. HM Govt accept mediation by third party to resolve Hon dispute / 6 Jul 1965 Washington. UK and Guat ask US to mediate, for which is named Webster / Apr 1966 Webster interim proposal presented confidentially / 8 Jun 1966 Trinidad. Daily Mirror [Trinidad] breaks story re Webster mediation, which Belize Billboard picks up / 26–28 Jun 1966 Belize T. Civil unrest re Webster mediation, w Guat Consul to Hon feeling threatened /v Lujan 6 164–165 /// 18 Apr 1968 Washington. Final Webster proposal presented / 28–29 Apr 1968 Belize T. Leg Co reject Webster proposal / 20 May 1968 Lon. HM Govt or Eng Parl reject Webster proposal / 20 Sep 1968 Washington. US exits Hon border or sovereignty mediation /v Lujan 6 166–167

NAME: Hart–Celler Act
DESC: US Congress enact Hart–Celler Act 1965, eliminating racial restrictions on immigration
NOTE: xnp

NAME: Alcalde records loss
DESC: Destruction or loss of records of vars alcaldes
NOTE: 1969 Hon. Last Garifuna villages removed fm alcalde jurisdiction, w all records of their official activities in court books lost or destroyed afterwards /v Moberg A 10

NAME: Alien Landholding Ord
DESC: Leg Assy pass Alien Landholding Ordinance
NOTE: xnp

NAME: TV est

Mahler, Tiny Belize gets its TV in unusual ways] /v Elliott N 5 / L. R. Robert Landis sells videocassette recorders and mails recorded programmes fm Miami /v Elliott N 36
